column10: b'b\' Thick lines unfortunately do not work well in WebGL: joins and ends look bad when applied in 3d space :( It\\\'s not even consistent
column11: you get flippings when rotating objects. Last time I looked into this
column12: people were doing crazy workarounds constructing "lines" from triangles.  If it\\\'s possible to address individual line primitive pixels (in a way similar to point sprites)
column13: maybe something could be done in shaders.  Anyways
column14: for your original request
column15: I think "proper" solution would be to use textures (for example generated in 2d canvas).  Also
column16: wireframe currently shows just triangles
column17: to be more true to what\\\'s really being rendered (OpenGL ES / WebGL doesn\\\'t have quad primitives)
column18: so you would get lines across cubes. I could change it to just 4 lines for quads if this is more desirable.\''

column10: b'b\' Aha
column11: I have seen now your screenshots. These are quite thin lines
column12: so double material (as you have) should be ok (if you are satisfied with performance).  Diagonal lines are exactly what I mentioned quads broken into triangles. This should be simple to fix. It\\\'s just a matter of convention should "wireframe" show our data structures (triangles and quads) or real rendered primitives (just triangles).\''

column10: b'b" Not in Blender
column11: that I would expect.  I meant if it did look ok in  with  ? Problem with transparency in WebGL is that you can\'t depth-sort triangles (well
column12: in principle you could
column13: but performance would go down the drain as sorting has to be done in JavaScript and also in each frame WebGL buffers would have to be reset that\'s what we do for particle billboards and they are much slower than opaque particles where you don\'t need to sort because for opaque things z-buffer works).  So if you have a model with transparent triangles that are one in front of each other
column14: then for some camera angles it would look ok
column15: but for many camera angles you will get very weird artefacts (like your model does). Black color what you see is in fact color of the background that shines through transparent pixels in triangles that have been rendered first."'

column10: b'b" So basically
column11: is a problem of having a an object with different transparent parts that need to be self composed with itself. That\'s something tricky for  to do (in contrast to CanvasRenderer...) So you should split the model in different parts so  can sort independenly these parts and compose them properly. If you want to get a hint of what is going on try this method:  "'

column10: b"b' It does.Becuase when you add the mesh to the scene
column11: that mesh gets a parent and gets added to the list of __objectsadded.Becuase that mesh has a parent and it needs to get another parent
column12: the mesh needs to be removed from the parent and scene
column13: so it get added to the list of __objectsremoved.Now the mesh gets added to the parent but it still is in the list of __Objectsremoved.That is why nothing shows up
column14: it gets removed directly after being added.'"

column10: b'b" So an object can\'t exist in 2 scenes?"'

b'b" a 3DObject can still be used in 2 or more scenes. explanation of my interpretation of the bug report: scene = new ();3Dobject1 = new 3Dobject();3Dobject2 = new 3Dobject();  But if you add a 3Dobject to a scene by saying: (3Dobject1);(3Dobject2);  Now the scene is the parent of 3Dobject1 and 3Dobject2. so  contains 3Dobject1 and 3Dobject2.  Now Later on
column11: you decide it would be better that 3Dobject2 needs to be a child of 3Dobject1 . so you do:  3Dobject1.addChild(3Dobject2);  Becuase 3Dobject2 already has a parent namely scene
column12: it first gets added to .and now 3Dobject2 gets added as a child of 3Dobject1 and becuase it is already in
column13: It doesn\'t get added. but when the rendering start it first adds 3DObject2 and removes it directly after that. so It doesn\'t get shown. Which seems to be what happens in the bugreport."'

column10: b'b" It may make sense to resurrect ajax model loader.  Long time ago we were loading models without workers
column11: but this was making problems for large models (UI thread freezes
column12: warning popups about unresponsive scripts
column13: exceptions
column14: or simply nothing happening).  But with canvas renderer large models are anyways not usable. The simplest probably would be to fetch via Ajax regular worker model string
column15: strip out worker parts and parse the rest as JSON (that\'s what Blender importer does)."'

column10: b'b\' I think IE should implement workers rather than people doing "hacks" so stuff works on IE. Haven\\\'t we learnt this lesson from IE6 yet? ;)\''
b"b' Yes i think IE has really shot themselves in the foot not supporting WebGL or web workers. People will stop using their browser if they can do cooler things elsewhere!'"

column11: they do use shaders
column12: but I don\'t know much about shaders so I have no clue as  these should be used in ... Shaders are basically Object3D\'s but on the GPU
column13: correct? Does  use shaders for particles?"'

column10: b"b' Everything in WebGL uses shaders
column11: the question is to which extent.  Particles in  use shaders for rendering
column12: SpiderGL demo uses shaders also for particles animation. You basically hardcode behavior into shader (with some parameters passed as attributes)
column13: as opposed to controlling particles from JavaScript. I guess you could do something similar in  using custom and custom attributes. '"

column10: b'b" Ah okay. So once a shader is created
column11: it \'lives on its own\' basically? There is no means of interacting with a shader? I imagine that the control for shaders then would become rather limited (not much beyond the SpiderGL demo at least).  Regardless
column12: would it be possible to \'cheat\' with the MeshShaderMaterial and make it not only do the rendering but also the position?"'

column10: b'b\' You can interact with shader
column11: you can pass uniforms (per-shader parameters) or change values of attributes (per-vertex parameters)
column12: just you can\\\'t change the code (without creating new shader). So for example for particles it means you could have "explosion" shader and modify how explosions look
column13: but if you wanted to have "swirl" behavior
column14: you would need a different shader. In theory
column15: you could combine multiple behaviors into single shader and switch between them online by uniforms
column16: but this would create heavy shaders (shaders are peculiar
column17:
if"s are costly, basically both branches get executed). Another option would be to programatically create behaviors in shaders out of "behavior chunks" in a similar way how currently materials are created out of rendering chunks (color, textures, lights, fog, reflections, etc) basically using instead of meaning if code is not used it\\\'s not even compiled in. But that would be quite complex endeavor, it would make more sense once we collect more use cases with hardcoded shaders / JS-driven particle effects to have idea which behavior chunks are commonly used.\''
threejs	329	closed	6	fabricasapiens	2011-07-06 13:59:49	32.03		+1		b'b" I see, so theoretically, to make an explosion and then a swirl, there are a few options:code all the action into the shader, and do a either the explosion or the swirl based on a uniform-value (but this is costly due to an if-statement)create two shaders (or one shader with two behaviour chunks of which only the relevant chunk is compiled, effectively resulting in two different \'shader-instances\'). Do the explosion, then change the shader for the swirl-version.create a shader that depends on uniform-values for its position and rotation, then update those from javascript. This is I guess how it\'s currently done in  ?"'
threejs	329	closed	7	mrdoob	2011-07-06 13:59:49	34.92			+1	b"b' Actually, in this test I was handling 500.000 particles :) url '

column11: the buffers get saved in the objects themselves instead of in the renderers. And the renderers check if there is a buffer already created in the object before creating it. So they all use the buffer that it\'s assigned to the first gl instance."'

column10: b"b' Web Worker compatibility'"

b'b" I\'ve been finding Web Workers to be indispensable when processing lots of data to render on screen. You can use them to keep performance smooth by creating geometries in the Web Workers and sending them over to the client window where they\'ll be turned into meshes and added to the scene. I was thinking I\'d go through the code and make any references to the window object be compatible with web workers. I\'d also like to add a new build file called  that will include everything in common_files and also the files from extras that you need to work with geometries. I figure that most people working with Web Workers won\'t need scenes

b'b" I think it should be pretty safe. I was just being pre-cautious with that second statement before :).  window and self should be exchangeable. However
column11: Web Workers don\'t have a window reference.  By the geometry generators you\'re talking about those classes like  and ? Those are great for when you have a predefined model you just want to load up
column12: but there are cases where you may want to construct a geometry from a dataset that is not vertices and faces
column13: or maybe you want to run a complex algorithm on it before generating the geometry. Also
column14: imagine 3D data visualizations where I want to create a mesh based off of some dataset like the human genome
column15: or demographics across a country... And then!
column16: imagine doing that while keeping it performing well enough for the user to interact with it :) In my case I\'m creating an infinite procedurally generated world of blocks that I generate on the server in the form of one byte per block. Then on the client-side I process that data to generate the geometries
column17: and do visualization checks. I\'ve seen at least one other person do something similar. url  This guy is actually using
column18: but to generate the mesh he\'s actually calculating the vertices and normals manually in the Web Workers
column19: sending them back to the client window
column20: and rendering the mesh using plain ol\' WebGL. Actually
column21: I only see him using  for the camera and matrix \'d be great to take advantage of  in a case like this. And and we have to do is change a couple lines :)  "'

column11: it just goes frame by frame and bakes actual state of meshes for each frame. So for your use case
column12: I guess in Blender you would need to: 1) have just two frames 2) first frame is thin book3) second frame is thick book Then for playback
column13: horse is wrong example to look at (looping interpolation between sequence of frames).  You need more something like this (controlled blending between several morph shapes): url  OBJ converter trips on incorrect MTL file exported from Blender as there is no material defined for the book
column14: Blender\'s OBJ exporter just puts empty string as material id. Try adding some material to the book. For OBJ pipeline
column15: principle is the same
column16: each individual OBJ (there should be just two of them) should contain visibly different mesh state (has to be the same mesh
column17: just vertex position would be different)."'

column11: there were some fixes for handling of specular and ambient terms both in standard Phong and normal map shader. You may need to redo your material / lights settings. If I remember well

column13: so you may need to tweak scene / material ambient.'"

column10: b"b' @alteredq With regards to interpolated frames
column11: it is important to note that Maya itself only plays back animation on each frame.  It does not do interpolated between frames. On the other hand
column12: MotionBuilder does interpolate between frames on playback.  Even scrubbing the timeline you can smoothly move between frames and see sub-frame animation.  But with Maya
column13: playback and timeline scrubbing only plays on-frame keyframes in order to preserve accurate keyframe animation. Anyways
column14: while it is nice to play back an animation using interpolated sub-frame keyframe values in order for it look smoother
column15: a lot of the time it is more important to maintain accurate playback.  If subframe keyframe interpolation was to be implemented I would hope that it would be 100% optional.'"

column13: but euler\'s integration will get greater accumulated error of margin if delta\'s are too big over time."'

column10: b"b' @alteredq Yayay! ^^'"
b"b' @alteredq not really. i feel that the bottleneck is pushing the buffers from CPU to the GPU every time you need to render. while JS is slow
column11: simulating a million particles in still is faster than rendering a million particles to screen
column12: so where it chokes is still requestAnimationFrame()
column13: unless the pipeline is all in the gpu
column14: imho.'"

column10: b'b" @zz85 Did some tests with million particles (not
column11: just move things around in JS using and ): 60 fps without setting dirty flag and no JS computation25 fps with just dirty flag (new buffers are sent to GPU every frame)7 fps with just JS computation (new values are computed every frame but not sent to GPU) So yes
column12: sending stuff to GPU is expensive
column13: but doing lots of even trivial things in JS can be surprisingly costly (for some reason this triggers massive garbage collection
column14: I already encountered such behaviors before
column15: you don\'t need to allocate anything
column16: if you do lots of something
column17: it\'ll cause garbage collection)."'

column10: b'b" So far
column11: I\'ve followed the [tutorial]url  that suggested to call requestAnimationFrame() and render in a loop. This bug caused my page to hog 1-2 CPU cores forever
column12: even if nothing at all is happening in the scene
column13: as long as my webpage was open
column14: for days. It drains battery
column15: uses electricity needlessly
column16: and spins up fans. Thus
column17: causing noise pollution and indirectly environmental pollution. Needless to say
column18: that\'s a (page) killer. I was so frustrated
column19: I was seriously trying to rewrite everything using another 3D library. (SceneJS doesn\'t seem to have the same problem.) Finally
column20: I realized that my scene only changes on user input. Therefore
column21: I made my call to requestAnimationFrame() conditional on whether there was a user input in the last 2 seconds. If not
column22: I would go into standby mode and not call requestAnimationFrame(). As soon as there\'s new action
column23: I call render() again. Here\'s my code: Super-ugly. But this solved my problem. The CPU usage drops from 2 cores with 100% each to almost nothing
column24: after 2 seconds of no activity on my page. Your situation may wary
column25: you may other factors other than user input that cause scene changes for you. But maybe it\'s a lot less than every 16ms
column26: and more importantly
column27: there may be phases of complete inactivity when you can turn things off entirely until some trigger. (In my case: mouse move) I hope this helps. I still consider this to be a band-aid and ugly
column28: and I think this should be fixed in ThreeJS. If nothing else
column29: to save all our CPU cores on all the pages that use ThreeJS."'

column10: b'b\' Current implementation of shadow maps is quite sensitive to differences in numbers
column11: you need to have not just structure of code the same
column12: you need also to get the numbers to be "right" (how big are objects
column13: where exactly is light
column14: how big is light frustum
column15: shadowmap bias). For example here: url  Relevant relative sizes / positions are: The key is to have things positioned / scaled to fit well into light\\\'s frustum. In theory it should be possible to set this up from scratch
column16: but it\\\'s much easier just to "clone" working example start from the existing scene with working shadows where you add your own objects and then remove the old scene (or "transplant"  back to your application).\''

column10: b"b' Could be some depth-precision artefacts. Shadow maps use scene depth rendered from a point of view of light and are sensitive to where in light frustum things are.  There are tweakable parameters for light frustum:   in particular is very sensitive.  I think our depth encoding to RGBA has some troubles. I tried to reuse recently its float ='"
b"b' Hmm... maybe I need to tune the shadowCameraFov down as the distance goes up
column11: right? What is shadowMapBias exactly?'"

column10: b"b' There is a tradeoff between coverage and precision. You want to make your light frustum as tight as possible to encompass scene part visible from the camera but not more. Bias is magic offset number to help with self-shadowing artefacts: url '"
b"b' Thanks!'"

column10: b'b" I have suspicion we may have a new bottleneck somewhere in  . This is probably not related to complexity of objects or number of objects
column11: these code paths are very optimized.  What we don\'t do well out-of-box is dealing with many different materials (this can be helped by turning off depth-based sorting and manual sorting of scene graph by material).  And then there are textures. So far we didn\'t have examples with many textures. Yours and the one in that other issue both have many textures and both have performance problems. Given that there are other WebGL demos with many textures that are fast
column12: it\'s possible we may do something silly somewhere. I\'ll need to look into this."'

I will be glad to help ;)"'

b'b" I tried to replicate your issue in some more controlled test but I didn\'t succeed much when adding more textures I was getting fast performance up to a certain point and then Chrome just keep crashing instead of getting bad performance. Exact number of textures depended on size of textures I was able to get 100 textures of 1024x1024 at 60 fps or 1000 textures of 256x256 at 45 fps. Then I checked your live example again and now it was even much slower. I checked network traffic and it seems your models are unnecessarily overcomplicated  there were 1227 requests
column11: tons of tiny textures
column12: most of them not power of 2 sized (which means Loader will need to create thousand 2d canvases and use them instead of just use images).  Having models like this is bad not just for rendering but also for your server even small number of visitor will kill it. I\'m afraid for good performance you\'ll need to have models created in some different way. It should be one (or few) large power-of-2 sized textures per building
column13: not hundreds of tiny few pixel sized textures for every detail. Edit: I checked the network traffic for the site in the other issue and it seems to be structurally similar tons of non-power-of-2 sized textures when I walked around the whole gallery
column14: it generated 466 requests."'

column12: I exported again the model to .js and I have the same "Deprecated file format" message  after taking a look to JSONLoader source code in both and branches
column13: I found out that the problem was that the 3DMax exporter has a bug: it justs forgets to write the key on file metadata. Example: File just exported: "metadata":{"sourceFile": "001.max"

column18: basically just static plates that I\'d normally just layer on top in After Effects in multiply mode. Is there a straightforward way to do something like this? \\xe2\\x80\\xa2 Floor Reflections I\'d like some hint of glowing light from the wall and the screen reflected on the floor. What\'s a good way to fake this? Of course I\'d also like any other feedback on how I might tighten up the presentation
column19: etc. Best

column10: b'b\' Hmmm
column11: interesting. I think we\\\'ll need to improve postprocessing chain to be able to do effects you want. For the fake DOF you could use masking (with  )
column12: but it would need to be inverted effects later in chain applying only where there is nothing rendered
column13: instead of the current way where effects apply only where something is rendered. See dotted head here: url  I\\\'ll look into this
column14: I intended to do inverted masking some day
column15: now you found a use case ;) For image overlays
column16: I guess you could make that would take extra texture(s) input and do the proper mix. Something like shader
column17: just with a simple multiplication instead of  : url  Maybe we could have shader(s) for doing all standard blending modes: url  For floor reflections
column18: I don\\\'t know yet. I still didn\\\'t figure out some nicer
column19: more generic / automatic way of doing these things.  Usual trick is to have mirrored copy of the stuff you want to "reflect" placed below the real thing and overlaid with some semi-transparent plane. url url \''

column10: b"b' And inverse masking is in: url  I updated postprocessing example to show how to use it to blur the background. '"
b'b" I\'d like to agree with Jungalero
column11: it would be great to be able to sandwich effect passes between render passes in future! I tried something similar and also didnt work! I think the Composer has enormous potential if it was made a bit more flexible. I read an interesting article about renderer pipe-lining that suggested putting the Composition phase onto a separate thread. Is there any reason I couldn\'t do this using a web worker? url Look at slides 233 and beyond. "'

column10: b'b" I think sandwiching doesn\'t work because z-buffer gets destroyed with postprocessing passes. These things are surprisingly tricky. One day... Meanwhile
column11: render to texture is probably the way to handle such things
column12: using like Photoshop.Web workers are currently quite limited. You can\'t access DOM
column13: you can\'t render anything there
column14: just pass in and out JSON or typed arrays. They are basically good just for numerical computations
column15: string manipulations
column16: etc.  If I remember well though there were some plans to make it possible to do some more WebGL things in workers.Nice presentation
column17: thanks for the link. John Hable is great
column18: it\'s partly thanks to his proselytization we have gamma correct rendering option. Filmic tonemapping would be also nice
column19: just as far as I understood you need HDR with 16 bit colors not to get horrible artefacts
column20: so this would make everything much more bandwidth heavy. Could be still worth a try. RGBM encoding from the presentation looks very interesting. SSAO is in the works ;)."'

column11: bounbindBox may be null

column10: b'b" Bounding box is not used internally for anything
column11: it\'s there in case you need it somewhere at the application level. It\'s not computed at all anywhere automatically
column12: you need to compute it yourself. Bounding sphere is used for frustum culling and with /  . It\'s computed automatically just on creation of objects. You need to recompute it manually if you change vertices (change positions
column13: add / remove vertices)."'

column10: b"b' thanks for the clarification @alteredq  What about the inconsistency in .computeBoundingBox() ? should we add the following code ? it would make it consistent with the constructor (it assume if no vertices
column11: then bounbingBox === null) ps: computeBoundingSphere() is inconsistent too. but in a slightly different way.'"

column10: b'b" If there are no vertices than it doesn\'t matter what bounding box / sphere are. Though if for some reason you want to invalidate previous bounding box / sphere
column11: I guess setting values to zeroes would be preferable to nulling the objects
column12: as then if geometry would be reused again no new objects would need to be created."'

column10: b'b" That\'s probably because you are using alpha testing.  For visual rendering some parts of triangles are thrown away but for shadows whole mesh is visible.  Solution is to use custom depth material matching the visible material.  You can create custom depth material as by copying shader
column11: adding there uniform with your texture and then using this to invisible fragments in the same way how you do it for the visible material. url "'

column10: b'b\' You can try to play with  .  Your particular model + light direction setup seems to respond best to small negative bias. I got somehow okeish shadows with  :  ![aion]url  Just seems you\\\'ve got your material too bright
column11: probably to compensate for self-shadowing
column12: you need to tune ambient and directional lights; shadows look more "in place" when lighting is different: ![aion]url  Also make light frustum as tight as possible (in all six planes). Plus as this model has a lot of open surfaces
column13: you may want to try setting: This will get you different type of artefacts.  This is a complex model seen from very close
column14: so I think there\\\'ll always be some artefacts. You\\\'ll need to experiment and see what looks the best. Tweaking shadow maps is more art than science. If you play with numbers (light frustum
column15: shadow bias
column16: light direction
column17: shadow map resolution)
column18: you\\\'ll get a feel for what are tradeoffs.\''

column10: b'b\' That looks much better than before ;)Shadow map is computed from the real geometry
column11: so things that are just "painted" on surface have no effects (like smooth shading or normal maps)
column12: the only thing that enters shadow computation is mesh outline. But these artefacts on the face are not caused by this. Most likely it\\\'s coming from light direction vs triangles orientation. Some combinations perform really badly (more parallel the worse). You can try to move your light in different directions
column13: you may hit better or worse artefacts. Also you can try to turn off shadow filtering: This will give you different type of artefacts. Not really
column14: this would be more complicated
column15: you would need to somehow compute shadows from normal map separately in normal map shader and mix them with shadows from shadowmapping. I think this is done by raycasting using heightmap and in general is really slow.It\\\'s > And a bit of offtopic how to create on GitHub formatted text like in url  In "GitHub Flavored Markdown" I\\\'ve only found \''

column12: but then it would just look uglier. We would need something like this: url  Variance shadow maps however come with own specific artefacts
column13: in some situations there are very ugly light patches inside shadowed areas. And they are more expensive. Still may be worth trying. One day.You don\\\'t turn shadows  with  . It does exactly what it says
column14: it just stops updating shadow map (which means it "freezes" shadow
column15: if it was in some strange undefined state
column16: it\\\'ll stay like this). If you want to turn off shadows dynamically
column17: you will need to turn off shadow casting on all objects that cast shadow. Shadow receiving can\\\'t be turned off
column18: this is baked in materials
column19: but you can turn off shadow casting to achieve shadow-less look.Whatever works for you ;). That\\\'s beauty of git
column20: everybody works on own clone and if there some piece of code interesting for others
column21: they can merge it. Fixes for Opera would be interesting.\''

column10: b'b" We do have buffers for each object but I\'m not sure you can do raytracing in this way shaders see just individual vertices. Every example I\'ve seen so far does raytracing just on procedurally defined primitives
column11: baked directly in shaders. Check this thread for previous discussion #509"'

column10: b'b" By seeing individual vertices
column11: do you mean the vertex shader seeing only its current vertex?Yes
column12: same with the demos I\'ve seen so far ([Evan Wallace\'s]url  and others)
column13: based on simple primitives in parametric form in the fragment shader.What I aim to do is send down similarly simple data () just a lot of it
column14: and taken from actual geometry.  [This paper]url  (part 3.1.2) illustrates it pretty well it uses textures to send the data to the shader
column15: but [uniform buffer objects]url  should do the job better.Can those buffers be read by the shader as they are? If I can pass data to shaders through uniforms
column16: and the shader can traverse and do the simple intersection tests against it
column17: then why couldn\'t it be achieved the principle\'s the same
column18: isn\'t it?"'

column10: b"b' Indeed.The only way how to get data to shaders in WebGL are uniforms
column11: attributes and textures (i.e. there are no uniform buffer objects or some other OpenGL things). Attributes are per vertex
column12: uniforms and textures are per object. With uniforms
column13: you only get something over 200 x vector4 (in ANGLE
column14: with OpenGL you get more
column15: but not by that much). So the only feasible option seems to be textures. '"

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: thanks
column12: that lays it out pretty well for me didn\'t know WebGL doesn\'t have UBOs.[]url  looks like the way to go
column13: with data from . Cheers for the clear advice
column14: and if you have any other pointers or thoughts I\'d be glad to hear them.  Thanks."'

column10: b'b\' Hey
column11: reopened the issue for you. I was thinking of doing the same before having each object use a "raytracing shader" but every approach I\\\'ve seen uses a quad facing the camera as a virtual screen
column12: with the raytracing taking place in its shader see [Evan Wallace\\\'s app]url  for example and now I\\\'m leaning that way
column13: passing information from a reference scene to it in DataTextures so it can draw it. The reference information needed is:The primitives their geometry is made of triangles
column14: for simplicity which ray intersections are done againstTheir model-view matrices for transforming the vertices
column15: since they\\\'re only stored relative to the object\\\'s position on the CPU; transformation is done in the shader
column16: and the intersections need to be done against their global positionsColour information texturesWhatever else you need I\\\'m using their bounding spheres as part of an approach to accelerating the intersection tests These DataTextures would go in a sort of heirarchy (see the section of the paper referenced above)
column17: and the screen shader would then have access to all the global information about the reference scene it needs. This approach may need some changes to the renderer the reference scene must be updated
column18: but not actually rendered (only the screen needs to be rendered) and I\\\'m not sure if it\\\'s a good way to do it or not; but as for your two questions:I would pass all geometry down in one texture
column19: all matrices in another
column20: etc.
column21: in a logical heirarchy
column22: as opposed to one uniform per object it\\\'s more flexibleThe DataTexture takes an array of data which would come from  but bear in mind that these are untransformed as they are you need to apply each object\\\'s model-view matrix to its vertices in the shader to get their global positions\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m not exactly sure what you mean here.  The fragment shader accumulates the colour for each pixel based on ray-object intersections starting with the ray from the "eye" to its position the pixels don\\\'t keep getting "painted" by other shaders or anything.  That one fragment program accumulates the final colour for each pixel shown in that object
column11: you wouldn\\\'t do it again.\''

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: I see.  You\'re saying that the first object should accumulate the shaded colour of the second?You actually just recalculate the colour for the second one
column12: and accumulate that using the same diffuse
column13: ambient
column14: specular
column15: shadow
column16: refraction
column17: etc. calculations as normal.  This calculation
column18: in turn
column19: sends out other rays
column20: which intersect other objects
column21: and so on until the maximum number of bounces is reached. The way you were saying would almost be like a breadth-first method calculate the first bounce for everything
column22: then the second bounce (using colour information from the first)
column23: and so on.  I\'ve never heard of ray tracing being done that way
column24: don\'t know if it would even be possible.But
column25: in shaders
column26: you would do it depth-first calculate all the bounces for the first one
column27: then all for the second
column28: and so on always recalculating the colours at each intersection."'

column10: b"b' Actually it is the exact opposite
column11: the second object should accumulate the color of the first

column10: b'b" When do you try to tessellate?  It only works if you do it before the first render of the object. You can\'t change number of triangles after geometry buffers are baked. url  Also normals shouldn\'t really change with tessellation and centroids
column11: well
column12: it\'s up to you. If you don\'t use them
column13: no need to update. If you do use them
column14: you can update them explicitly after tessellation."'

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: you\'re right: I tried to dynamically tessellate an object and was wondering why it didn\'t work.  Thanks for the link it clarifies everything!"'

column10: b'b" So I realized there was indeed something that wasn\'t handled well with tessellation vertex normals and vertex colors.  For face normals and face colors
column11: new faces can just get the values from the old ones
column12: but for vertex ones you need to interpolate for mid points and assign them in proper vertex order. I fixed this in my branch: url url  There are still vertex tangents left
column13: but there I\'m not sure about interpolation
column14: there it\'s probably better just to recompute them."'

column10: b"b' @bak85 one more reply... The local x-direction and the global x-direction are the same at the start. When you rotate around the local x-direction only
column11: the local yand zdirections change
column12: but the local x-direction remains the same as the global x-direction. Make sure you read so you know what it does. Also
column13: usually you do not need to call that routine yourself; between renderings
column14: you can set rotations and translations (once)
column15: and the renderer will call for you.'"

column10: b"b' HUD over render in webgl'"
b"b' Hello
column11: i am interested in creating a HUD in webgl. I know html can be used to overlay over the scene
column12: but having the UI accelerated on the card can have some mighty advantages
column13: mostly integration with the rest of the app
column14: 3D  and shader special effects. I was wondering if there was a way to dual render a scene and  it. For example to render a a first time with a perspective camera
column15: and then render a second HUD layer on top with an orthographic camera and blend it with the first. thanks'"

column10: b"b' related to this i also have a question. Knowing that html compositing over the webgl canvas is done on CPU (ouch!)
column11: is it more efficient performance wise to double render (ortho over perspective)(render-to-texture perhaps?) or to let the browser do it on CPU? thanks'"

column10: b"b' Not really. At least on Chrome and Firefox page compositing is done on the GPU
column11: already for quite a while. '"

column10: b"b' that is REALLY good to know! thanks :) so i guess if this is
column11: the cost of  compositing is good in a modern browser?'"

column10: b"b' Yup. There was a marked increase in performance when they changed it.'"
b"b' i managed to create the effect i wanted by creating 2 scenes and 2 cameras
column11: one perspective and one ortho. I then render the first scene with the first camera
column12: setting autoclear on the renderer first to clear the surface. Then
column13: i turn off autoclear and render the second hud scene with the second ortho camera
column14: effectively compositing both
column15: the hud over the other. now to the experts out there
column16: would this technique of double render be more efficient (performance wise) than using html and letting the browser composite the whole thing in GPU or is there really no gain at all and using  over the canvas is just as good? (again the goal is to maximise fps performance) many thanks :)'"

column10: b'b\' actually
column11: i was just thinking of another potential solution. i guess we could overlap a canvas2d over the canvas3d and then draw on the canvas to do the "ortho" hud. now the question becomes
column12: how does performance compare between:2x render in pure webgl (ortho over perspective) compositing over the webgl canvas and let browser compositedraw on canvas2d over webgl canvas3d and let browser composite interesting to know for design choices
column13: thanks!\''

column10: b'b" I think you\'ll need to test and try. But I suspect the 2x render in pure webgl would be the best option. The last time I asked a question like that to a browser developer the answer was that I should try to rely in the browser as least as possible."'

column10: b'b" We are seeing this firefox performance issue very bad on our project which has dojo UI elements floating over the webgl canvas.  Chrome handles this like a champ and firefox drops ~10 FPS for every overlayed UI element.  What\'s interesting is that opening firebug also dramatically decreases the frame rate too.  The frame rate stays crippled even when the firebug console is closed again.  You can try this on the url  example.  It does not get better again unless I totally deactivate firebug.  This is not an issue for chrome and the chrome debugger.  I mention this because the debugger is just a fancy web user interface and this shows that firefox cannot handle rendering both a webgl canvas and a fancy dom based UI at the same time.  This is the first place that I found of anyone else noticing the issue
column11: so I thought I would chip in with what I am seeing."'

column11: I can give some feedback as the issue is 2 years old
column12: I just focus on cons : ## HTMLIt really sucks to animate a cursor.  In my case I had to build all animations of the cursor in a canvas (one canvas per animation)
column13: get back the data URI of the canvas
column14: decode the base64 to get the image content
column15: store it in a blob url and use the blob url in the rendering loop to bind the css cursor with the url.Need to check that your  is cross browser (few work).You inherit browser problem. For example it\'s a big pain to work with a scrollbar in a draggable UI element. ## WebGLHave to rebuild a whole HUD system with event handler.If your app run at 5 FPS
column16: the UI will not be responsive and that sucks ! That\'s not the case of the HTML still smooth even if you have 1FPS. ## CanvasSame thing than WebGL.Not so fast.The font rendering is really ugly and is browser AND GPU dependent. I personally decide to use HTML
column17: and to be honest I have some complexes elements and I don\'t see a boost penalty. In all case it depend of what the dev need to do."'

column12: I think I understand what\'s going on. The final object is constructed via merging of tons of individual components. It\'s pretty big by itself but still quite fine. Now before
column13: with these temporary objects were just garbage collected after they served their purpose.  But since we added these object / material / geometry libraries
column14: this prevents garbage collection and these temp objects just stay around forever and increase memory consumption. And now comes the kicker in our regular usage even if we missed something like that
column15: not much would happen. But because this application is so memory hungry
column16: doubling the memory use (sum of all temp objects + final object) pushes it over some magic Chrome limit which makes everything extremely slow. I just run into that magic limit elsewhere few days ago
column17: just testing something in console. I was increasing array size and after some number there was a huge performance cliff. I assume due to some swapping or something like that. @tarelli Easy way to test this theory would be to add deallocations after using temp objects for merging. If this turns out to be true
column18: it would be kinda perfect example how dangerous these libs are."'

column10: b'b" But that\'s kinda my point
column11: we both completely missed the implications of these libraries for one code pattern we use quite often ourselves creation of larger objects out of many smaller ones.  It\'s dangerous exactly because if you aren\'t aware of these dangling references all the time
column12: you\'ll run into this type of issues. Which is what garbage collection tries to free your mind from.  I came from C/C++ background where you don\'t have garbage collection. Memory management bugs are constant source of pain in that world.We need these libs to help to debug problems that they themselves cause ;)"'

column10: b'b" But the thing is
column11: this code not only helps when debugging but also highlight the use of bad practices. I\'m not sure if it\'s a good idea for people to assume that they can create things and not care about it because magically the GC will clean their mess. You\'re proposing the scenario of having a butler that cleans after the children
column12: and I\'m proposing teaching the children to clean after themselves. In the long term
column13: what\'s better?"'

column10: b'b\' If history of programming is any indication in general case it\\\'s better to have a butler and only take care of cleaning yourself in specific performance-critical cases ;) Believe me
column11: having a garbage collection is a major major productivity boost.  I suspect you are optimistic mostly because you do not realize how much you already depend on "butler".\''

column10: b'b" I guess a valid point would be that we could also check for a situation like this... Oh well
column11: I\'m going to miss being able to see exactly what\'s going on :)"'

column10: b"b' Non-renderable PolyMesh intermediate class to make factories
column11: importers
column12: exporters and modifiers more generic?'"

column10: b'b" This is a tentative idea.  So feel free to shoot it down. I am interested in creating an intermediate format that is separate from Threejs\'s renderable Geometries.  I believe that such a format would make a lot of ThreeJS\'s geometry factories
column11: importers
column12: exporters and modifiers more reusable
column13: and thus increase the number of uses for ThreeJS and also increase the flexbility of ThreeJS.  I also believe that this can be done at a fairly low cost to ThreeJS in terms of real-time performance. PolyMeshes would also be the type created by the various Geometry factories instead of the Geometry type.  This would make the factories simpler to write because this format isn\'t trying to make a directly rendering representation (which involved additional data.)  It would also mean that the internal ThreeJS renderable representation can change without having to change the factories
column14: imports and exporters.  Thus it gives ThreeJS more flexibility to evolve as only the converters  the PolyMesh. I believe that that the speed hit is minimal as most conversions will happen at  time
column15: not during run-time rendering. Side note: I\'ve already created such a class over the last week with the various converters.  I am wondering if I should put this into ThreeJS or whether I should put it in a separate library.  I don\'t mind if you don\'t want it in ThreeJS
column16: although I do think it would be valuable."'

column10: b'b\' I am not sure this can be fixed. The desire was to be able to use the same UVs that uses. That way
column11: a standard earth map could be used as a texture for this geometry
column12: too. The problem is
column13: that faces on the "seam" are split in half
column14: resulting in one half of the face being on the left edge of the UV map
column15: and the other half being on the right edge. This could be fixed by replacing each face on the seam with two faces
column16: but then the geometry would no longer be an icosahedron. ![Screen Shot 2013-04-07 at 6 28 21 PM]url  ![Screen Shot 2013-04-07 at 6 26 24 PM]url  An alternate solution is to unroll the geometry into a flat array of equilateral triangles
column17: but I\\\'m not sure it would be practical to use. A final solution is to not specify a UV map at all.\''

column10: b"b' Yet another solution would be to try to find these faces and +1 the U. Then wrapping will need to be set to tiled though.'"
b"b' @mrdoob Can you please explain your last comment? I do not understand what you are referring to.'"
b"b' Basically detecting the faces with vertices that are both in 360 and +1 the U of the vertices that are >360.  That way the U
column11: instead going going from 1 to 0.1
column12: it will go from 1 to 1.1.'"

b"b' Intersect should not pick invisible objects'"

b'b" #2277 was closed without comment.  A ray should not intersect invisible objects; a cursory reading of the source doesn\'t appear to show any check for visible at all in that part of the code.  And yes
column11: I realize you could iterate the returned objects but I still maintain that it shouldn\'t be checking invisible objects at all.  Or at least it could be a parameter somewhere."'

column10: b'b" Basically
column11: used to ignore invisible objects for a while
column12: but then there were people that needed those to be checked too. So
column13: instead of overcomplicating the code I opted for letting the user handle that instead. So if you want Raycaster to not check invisible objects don\'t add those to the list of objects you\'re passing."'

column10: b'b\' I already encounter this "issue"...Is there a reason why we can\\\'t have a simple boolean "pickable" set to true by default in Object3D ? Because right now if you got a huge scene with half of your object invisible your only option is to kept one array with the pickable stuffs and another with the invisible which might not be convenient. (you could also pick everything and take the nearest visible picked object but it would mean unnecessary computation...) The only drawback (imho) for the "pickable" solution is the overhead a single "if" test in the raycasting....\''

column10: b'b" Long term
column11: I\'d like to put together a more automated test suite. Something that looks like  ![testing-sample]url  With the main viewer on the top
column12: the snapshot on the bottom
column13: and some extensions to Chai to compare images. In this setup
column14: automated testing would include Chai tests to load a page
column15: send some types of events ( input)
column16: and compare the snapshot against some reference data. In the trails example
column17: for instance
column18: the dev would get the dataURL at frame 60 with no mouse input
column19: and then future runs would compare at that point. If the images are 100% identical
column20: they would pass. 90 to 100% would mark the test in yellow
column21: under 90% would be failing. (In the example image
column22: the bottom pane is an tag whose attribute was set by polling the from the 3D canvas at a point in time.)"'

column10: b'b" Aha! I sorted it out. Turns out
column11: there _was_ a difference in the stencilBuffer settings for this example
column12: but not because of browser incompatibility or renderer settings. It was hidden in the way that example sets up the separate composers for the different sections. When the composers in the example are constructed
column13: they\'re each given a new WebGlRenderTarget
column14: **which has the stencilBuffer parameter explicitly set to true**: I had initially assumed that the WebGLRenderTarget setting had to do with the fact that the example renders into four different places
column15: and so didn\'t think to copy the rtParameters.  There is a **lot** going on in this example
column16: and I haven\'t been able to find any other (working
column17: obvious) examples of using MaskPass correctly. Would it help to have a simplified version
column18: since it\'s a tricky maneuver and requires setting up the composers in a very particular way?"'

column10: b"b' Yep. A simpler example would be good to have.'"
b"b' Logarithmic depth buffer support'"
b'b\' I\\\'ve added logarithmic depth buffer support to .  This allows a constant range of z-buffer precision over the whole scene
column11: rather than the normal linear z-buffer which concentrates all of the precision closest to the near plane.  See url  for a full technical run-down of the problem and the solution. When active
column12: this allows the camera to have a camera near plane of 0 and a far plane of any size
column13: without suffering z-fighting or tearing of geometry.  I\\\'ve created a "stress test" example which shows off a very large scene (far plane = 1e24) with a wide range of object sizes (from 1 micrometer to 120
column14: 000 light years).  The same scene is displayed with both normal and logarithmic z-buffers
column15: for comparison.  The example is viewable online here: url ~.  A video of the example is available on youtube: url  This optionally makes use of the EXT_frag_depth webgl draft extension
column16: which is currently available in the latest Chrome stable release
column17: behind the "Enable WebGL draft extensions" option in about:flags.  This extension helps fix a degenerate case with large
column18: insufficiently-tesselated polygons too close to the camera. The option is activated by passing logarithmicDepthBuffer: true as an argument when instantiating WebGLRenderer: When active
column19: this option includes some ShaderChunks in the vertex shader for all of \\\'s included materials which modify gl_Position.z.  If the EXT_frag_depth extension is available
column20: it also sets gl_FragDepth in the fragment shader.\''

column10: b"b' Excellent demo
column11: IMHO. Under what conditions would it be better NOT to use logarithmic depth buffer mode? When enabled
column12: how does this effect the  [examples]url '"

column10: b'b" It is slower because of the use of EXT_frag_depth because it forces the GPU to bypass a lot of it\'s normal fragment discard behavior."'
b'b\' Linear depth buffer performs a bit better at extremely close-up objects (compare the "microscopic" object across both versions)
column11: given a small enough near-plane value although the logarithmic method also gives you a near-plane of 0
column12: so it\\\'s a bit of a trade-off.  For instance
column13: in the Stanford Bunny demo url ~/#webgl_loader_vtk) the model is sufficiently tesselated than you can get incredibly close to the model without any visible clipping. Most of the examples work fine with the logarithmic depth buffer enabled
column14: although it seems there are some problems with shadow mapping which I might need someone\\\'s help to figure out.  Demos which have a single large "ground plane" also have some rendering issues from that.  Logarithmic depth buffer\\\'s strengths are in scenes which need midto long-range visibility. gero3\\\'s comment about it being a bit slower is probably true
column15: but on the systems I\\\'ve tested with the performance difference was negligible (still capping out at 60fps on all examples).  It might be nice to build some sort of stress test example where we can determine what sort of difference this actually makes
column16: performance-wise.\''

column10: b'b" @WestLangley I think this is something that I would keep behind an option anyway.  I wouldn\'t advocate making it the default
column11: as with most things in computer graphics the technique has trade-offs but it would be an incredibly useful option to have for people working with large scenes.  Developers can make the choice themselves if the overdraw-related performance issues apply in their case. In my case I\'m using this option for a space simulator
column12: so you have vast spaces with not a lot of objects in them
column13: and the overdraw issues are negligible.  The type of scene where the performance issues come into play are scenes with lots of overlapping objects (like the webgl_performance example) the default linear depth buffer would be a better choice for that type of scene."'

column10: b"b' @jbaicoianu @gero3 Thank you for your explanations.'"
b'b" Thanks guys.  Still working through a couple of the bugs so let\'s hold off on merging this for now
column11: but I\'m making progress. Looks like the problems in url ~/#webgl_materials_texture_filters when EXT_frag_depth is enabled are simple z-fighting issues this example uses polygonOffset to influence the render depth of certain objects
column12: and from what I\'ve found in the OpenGL spec
column13: glPolygonOffset is applied before gl_FragDepth is processed
column14: so if you\'re setting gl_FragDepth directly
column15: glPolygonOffset is ignored. From the spec: So I think this means that when EXT_frag_depth is in use
column16: I have to pass in the polygonOffset as a uniform and reproduce what it does in the fragment shader.  Unless of course someone has any ideas on how to make glPolygonOffset and gl_FragDepth work together nicely?  I wonder if there\'s any other way to read the values that are set by glPolygonOffset from within GLSL?"'

column10: b'b" On the subject of performance
column11: the author of the technique mentions that one optimization they use is to only apply the gl_FragDepth calculation for objects within a certain range of the camera.  Not sure if this is something we could do automatically since as I\'ve implemented it (with #defines) it would require either a shader recompile or storing two copies
column12: but it\'s at least a possible optimization users can make in their application if they need to squeeze as much performance as they can out of it."'

column10: b"b' Jpeg2000 usage'"
b'b" Since there\'s by now quite a good Jpeg2000 support from browsers it might be worth digging into it. With jpeg2000 you could just clip it to receive a lower texture resolution
column11: so maybe using it for mipmaps (instead of generating them) might be very beneficial. Quite sure there are other good usecases too.If someone wants to do some elaborate work on this and figure out how and when to use it I\'d highly appreciate it ^^ Kind regards"'

column10: b"b' Do you mind elaborating a bit more on that? How does that work?'"
b'b" Sure. Well
column11: some facts about jpeg2000 first (aka j2k
column12: jp2
column13: etc.) from the top of my head
column14: compared to jpeg:roughtly 2-3 times smaller file size than JPEG for same quality2-3 times slower jpeg2000 algorithms (compression
column15: decompression)allows very strong compression (think textureatlases etc.)/ compression is very strong for large scale images
column16: not so much for smaller onesprogressive decoding with the wavelet system
column17: meaning: decode only 1/4th of your image (+ headers ofc) and you have a 256x256px image instead of your original 512x512 image! It took quite a while to achieve today\'s coverage (about 10 years?) but it might be worth elaborating:whether we can use the progressive decoding for e.g. mipmappinghow wide-spread it really is in terms of browser implementationwhether the compression outweighs the performance loss
column18: or in general: whether an implementation is worth our time :) If I can really shrink my 4096x4096px image by 2/3 of its size then this image format is reeeeeally worth considering! ^^ Searching for volunteers for some more elaborate research! :+1: "'

b"b' Refactor  into class definitions'"
b"b' The goal here is to move the logic for serialization and deserialization on to the class definitions. The and classes still exist as thin helpers
column11: that call out to the serialization methods implemented on the Classes themselves. This breaks up responsibility
column12: and allows custom classes to provide their own serialization methods. Updates #4609 '"

column10: b"b' This is still a work in progress
column11: but is mostly complete. I am starting this PR to get feedback. This refactor was structured to avoid breaking changes. I feel there are still some parts that are less than ideal. Materials are still deserialized by the MaterialLoader
column12: instead of providing their own deserialization methods. In a few places
column13: the use and naming convention of and feels a little weird. For the Object loading
column14: the instance is no longer being cached. I am still performing tests on these changes. Further deduplication of code may be possible elsewhere by having just serialize and deserialize the instance. I am happy to make any changes small or large
column15: let me know how I can improve this PR. cheers'"

column10: b"b' Add penumbra angle to spotLight'"

b'b\' Add an additional option to called  .This angle will be added to the angle of the spotlight to create a"falloff" cone. The area within both cones is lit as normal. The areaoutside of the falloff code is not lit. The area between the inner andfalloff cones is smoothly faded away as it approaches the edge of thefalloff cone. Before: ![screen shot 2014-07-17 at 9 52 16 am]url  After (10 degree penumbra): ![screen shot 2014-07-17 at 9 52 13 am]url \''

column10: b'b\' @WestLangley : Dragging things around on meshes is the problem. While we drag we need to know on every mouse move where we hit the mesh. The normal computers were never the problem
column11: but as soon as we tried to get a useable result on mobile devices we got a big problem. The raycasting was eating up the mobile CPU. With the new system we get a real good useability on iPad2 or Nexus Devices. There are so many functions that only needs a few milliseconds. But at 40fps we only got 25ms left to do anything at all. I hope we will launch the project in a few  and i will be happy to explain the problems in detail then :)  " There is so much time and so little to do. Wait a minute. Strike that reverse it. "\''

column10: b'b" It is more then a few weeks now.  (But isn\'t that always the problem with programming? :) )I just wonna to put in a last comment
column11: so you could see why there is a need for a better raycaster. Here is our current app where we encountered the raycaster speed problem:url  The problems we had with the normal raycaster:We dropped a text or a logo on a jersey. We wanted to track the position of the logo. So if we moved the logo around it was eating up the cpu usage. And even on a normal PC with firefox it was feeling a little bit laggy .  If we moved the logo the raycaster was eating up 95% of the CPU-Time.  With our simple BVHTree the raycaster is using only 2% of the CPU Time.  So if you always wonna track a mouse position on a mesh
column12: the normal raycaster is a little bit too slow.  And our meshes only have 5.000 faces (I think that\'s not big
column13: but i don\'t know).  I would be happy to test new raycasters :)  Until then we will use the simple LBVHTree.  best regards Benedikt"'

column10: b"b' Example for using ESLint to help enforce your style rules'"

b'b\' I just got done setting this up for one of my projects and I thought I\\\'d show you how to set it up for yours if you\\\'re interested. I\\\'m not expecting you to pull this request (you can if you want) but rather if you don\\\'t like it as is you can reference it. So
column11: if you get this branch
column12: cd to the root folder and type then you can now do and it checks many or most of your style rules. See that most of the rules are off right now because the code is breaking them all over the place :P Ideally if you add this to the official  repo we could turn on one rule
column13: fix all the warnings
column14: then make a pull request and repeat until its all one style.  It\\\'s currently only checking the folder. Ideally we\\\'d turn it on for the and folders as well. One thing I need to look into is how easy it would be it lint inline html scripts for the examples folder but hey
column15: one step at a time. So ... first that makes it easy to manually check if the code mostly matches your style guide but...## travis-ci if you setup a free account on travisand turn it onfor the  repo it will lint any pull request automatically and have the results directly in the pull request on github. I turned it on on my copy of  repo. [You can see it ran here]url ## git integration You can also setup a git pre-commit script to run "grunt eslint" beforecommitting. That\\\'s a local only thing meaning it won\\\'t propagate to otherusers but it might be useful for yourself if you want to make sure you don\\\'tcommit something that breaks your own rules## custom rules [ESLint]url  allows custom rules. The easiest way to make a custom rule is to copy one of the built in rules. So for example Now there\\\'s a rule called  . You could modify it so it enforced a blank line after and before  ## overriding rules Sometimes you need to override a rule for special code. You can do that with a comment in the code. For example if you wanted to allow an unused var you could do this  ## where to put these files I thought I should put all of these files in or  . The advantage to the latter is that you already have a file there that I\\\'m guessing you use. The reason I put a few files in the root though is because that way they work with travis-ci without much work. If you move them somewhere else I suspect there\\\'s a bunch of work to do to get travis-ci to handle that case. Of course it\\\'s up to you.\''

b"b' Resolved url '"
b"b' Vector3.applyMatrix4 inconsistencies'"

b'b" Currently Vector3.applyMatrix4 has a hidden assumption that the input matrix is affine. This is a very surprising and inconsistent behavior compared to Vector4.applyMatrix4. This issue was the root cause of the bugs in url  It seems like the change was introduced in url  for performance reasons. In that case I think the proper names should be:  Vector3.applyMatrix4  Vector3.applyProjection -since applyProjection is always safe and the other is an optimization you can take if you are sure the matrix is affine. It would also be great if there were some sort of debug build that has an ((e[ 3 ] \\\\* x + e[ 7 ] \\\\* y + e[ 11 ] \\\\* z + e[ 15 ]) == 1) to verify affineness to catch programmer errors. Are there any benchmarks to show that this is actually a worthwhile optimization? If not I don\'t see why you would want to restrict parts of the library to just using affine transforms. I think it is much saner to just collapse those two back into one function."'
b'b\' Actually
column11: comments in the code explicitly state the input matrix must be affine. The docs could be improved
column12: however.You cannot multiply a 3-component vector by a 4x4 matrix
column13: so the methods must be inherently different.It was also introduced because a perspective divide is only appropriate when applying a projection matrix
column14: and when a further mapping from clip-space to NDC space is desired.  performs a perspective divide. It is only "safe" if that is what you want to do.\''

column10: b"b' Using homogeneous coordinates should be fairly common in the graphics community. Most people will probably just assume that (x
column11: y
column12: z) is represented by (x
column13: y
column14: z
column15: 1) or equivalently
column16: (xw
column17: yw
column18: zw
column19: w) for some non-zero w
column20: before getting multiplied by the 4 by 4 matrix. The perspective divide is just for converting back to inhomogeneous (dividing by w)
column21: and of course this is always safe to do even when dealing with affine instead of projective transforms. This is a very nice chart stolen from this free ebook: url  that summarizes the hierarchy of transforms dealing with homogeneous coordinates:url Note that all 3x4 transforms in this chart should have a 4th row of (0

column10: b'b" Discussions trailed off
column11: but the bugs still exist: url  The bug in that demo was caused by using applyMatrix4 instead of applyProjection and can be fixed in a one-off way:  url But the real fix should be to implement Vector3.applyMatrix4 the same way as Vector3.applyProjection. The two already always return the same result for affine matrices
column12: but for non-affine applyMatrix4 is silently wrong. Why not just support the more general class of transforms? I think previous discussions got sidetracked talking about whether  can actually handle non-affine matrices but I think none of that really matters. This is the math sub-library and you shouldn\'t add a surprising special case to the well established mathematics of matrix-vector multiplication (or at least name it something less general than applyMatrix4 if you are going to do that).  I can send a PR to show what I mean more clearly but I will also understand if you guys don\'t care and want to keep this closed. (Even I don\'t have any real world use for this. I just can\'t get over getting burned by this unexpected behavior when I first ran into it.)  Sidenote: Current implementation of applyMatrix4 is confusing enough that whoever wrote the [documentation didn\'t even get it right]url  It describes it as a multiply with the first 3 columns but it should actually be a convert to homogeneous(add 1 on 4th dimension) then multiply with the first 3 rows. In other words it\'s the same as applyProjection but assuming affine where bottom row is [0
column15: 1] so the multiply on that row and perspective divide can be omitted. If you didn\'t have this marginally useful  you wouldn\'t have these confusions to begin with!"'

column10: b"b' Example: url '"
b"b' @WestLangley Thoughts?'"
b'b" @fta2012 wrote  >Even I don\'t have any real world use for this.  Hmm.  Listen
column11: url  is a reasonable change
column12: but it is ~ 33% more ops for a highly-used method.  Our method avoids the perspective divide because we know it is 1 for affine input matrices.  Another option is to change the method name to something like  .  Or
column13: we could leave it as-is
column14: and improve the documentation. Maybe @fta2012 would be willing to do that."'

column10: b'b" I would be pretty surprised if it\'s actually 33% slower (due to instruction level parallelism
column11: pipelining
column12: data already in cache
column13: etc). And it\'s premature optimization. I did a quick check with the chrome profiler and didn\'t find many examples where applyMatrix4 is called often enough to even show up in the profiler. The example with a bunch of [point lights]url  finally made it cost around 0.01% of total execution time:  ![applymatrix4]url That makes sense since you don\'t go transforming points individually all that often. Most of the cost is in multiplyMatrices:  ![multiplymatrices]url Anyway if you\'re still not convinced
column14: I give up!"'

WestLangley"  wrote:>\''
threejs	6039	closed	10	bhouston	2015-02-08 08:35:32	0.67		+1		b'b\' I have never liked the applyMatrix function name because it is ambiguousmathematically. Best regards,Ben Houstonurl  Online 3d modeling and rendering On Dec 18, 2016 11:13 AM, "Ben Houston"  wrote:>>>>>>>>\''
threejs	6039	closed	11	WestLangley	2015-02-08 08:35:32	40.77		+1		b'b" >I prefer separate multiply and project functions because they are different operations mathematically.  Actually, the OP is correct. They are not different operations mathematically. That is why, prior to #2921, when we had just one function for all  matrix types, it just worked.  The conceptual steps to apply any to a are  1. convert Vector3 to Vector4 by adding a w-component of 1 2. call Vector4.applyMatrix4() 3. divide each component by the new w-component. (w is now 1) 4. convert the Vector4 back to Vector3 by dropping the w-component.  We only need one method to do that. It is just that we don\'t have to do the divide step if we know the value we would divide by is 1.  As I said in #2921, I can go either way, but I am leaning toward reverting back now.  @bhouston Given your knowledge of other math libraries, can you check if they have separate methods?"'
threejs	6039	closed	12	bhouston	2015-02-08 08:35:32	1279.08	+1			b'b" IlmMath\'s multVecMatrix is unoptimized, it always does the divide: url gl-matrix from the venerable toji has one function:  url Unity 3D has a fast path that doesn\'t do the divide (MultiplyPoint3x4) and another that does (MultiplyVector):  url  url "'
threejs	6039	closed	13	bhouston	2015-02-08 08:35:32	2.5		+1		b'b\' I would lean towards one function that always does the divide if that is what others are doing.  I think that trying to micro optimize out the divide when the divisor is 1 isn\\\'t that valuable, and no one else is doing that.  I think that is because "if" tests are themselves costly when mispredicted.\''
threejs	6039	closed	14	WestLangley	2015-02-08 08:35:32	212.63			+1	b"b' @bhouston OK, you pushed me off the fence. :)  I will collapse and into one method, and avoid the conditional. will be removed.  Thanks @fta2012.'

column10: b"b' #extension directives should be before any non-preprocessor tokens (standard derivatives)'"
b'b\' ANGLE has a long standing bug where we would allow bad shaders with #extension directives after non-preprocessor tokens. After fixing this
column11: we noticed it would break some  samples
column12: for example
column13: url  This extends to other forks of  like xg. I noticed in
column14: in the prefix_fragment section
column15: you could place the #extension directive before the precision statements. If you fix this
column16: and update the sample above
column17: maybe that would fix this one particular instance. For reference
column18: the relevant section of the spec: "[ESSL 1.0.17 pg 15]Each extension can define its allowed granularity of scope. If nothing is said
column19: the granularity is a singlecompilation unit
column20: and the extension directives must occur before any non-preprocessor tokens. Ifnecessary
column21: the linker can enforce granularities larger than a single compilation unit
column22: in which case eachinvolved compilation unit will have to contain the necessary extension directive." The Chromium bug tracking these breaks: url  It would be nice if someone could take this up. Even if we can\\\'t make this change in Chrome very soon
column23: it would be good to stop new demos and forks of the code from having the issue if we do get to the point where we can switch the validation on
column24: to pass WebGL Conformance.\''

column13: it would go after this chunk: (and precisions)'"

b'b" @mrdoob well they say we\'re not allowed to place any actual code before #extension things
column11: but even if we put it on top of ShaderMaterial shaders
column12: it still prepends a lot of stuff
column13: so your way you would need to add separate flag for each and every possible extension that user might want to use. @benaadams thanks for pointer."'

column10: b'b" For what it\'s worth

column12: and on the desktop this particular rule isn\'t enforced either. Appreciate the fix to the existing extension code
column13: but no need to do any more work for now from ANGLE\'s perspective."'

column10: b"b' Hi all
column11: When I am choosing which  I would like to use in my app
column12: it basically boils down to: do I want no lighting (for computationally-challenged devices)
column13: flat diffuse only for cheap lighting
column14: or  for more realistic but still somewhat performant lighting
column15: or
column16: in the near future
column17: do I want a physically-based material and advanced lighting model for ultimate realism on a higher-end desktop that can handle it?  Here is a proposed list ranging from fastest-performing / least-realistic to slowest-performing but most-realistic:1. MeshBasicMaterial (no lighting model can be used
column18: just a pure color per-face)2. MeshFlatShadedMaterial (Lambert per-face lighting
column19: similar to  in MeshLambert)3. MeshGouraudMaterial (Lambert lighting model per-vertex only
column20: or Phong lighting could be used)4. MeshPhongMaterial (Blinn-Phong lighting model
column21: per-fragment only)5. MeshPhysicalMaterial (Cook-Torrance model
column22: etc. here could be added numerous BRDF options
column23: as many as those who are implementing this material option are willing to make for us). There is a nice
column24: intuitive progression in the above list from computationally cheapest to most expensive vs most-unreal to most -realistic.  Devs could tailor these material choices to suit the target device.'"

column10: b'b" @whknight But how do you know
column11: which normal to pick and output from a vertex then? The general idea is that we have vertices (for example a cube would have 8) and each of them get some value. Of course we could send 3 values or an entire array to each of them. But now there is a problem on how we interpolate the values to the faces. When the vertex shader has ran
column12: the next step is rasterization of faces and each raster (fragment) in a face has a fragment shader ran on it. The fragment shader can get values interpolated from neighboring vertices. Alas there is no way to send one value for a face located on one side of the vertex and another value to some other face.Unless you use the [provoking vertex]url  which is not available in WebGL yet. That would allow you to specify that only the value from the first / last vertex is used for the entire face. Maybe I didn\'t understand your idea fully and it certainly seems worth thinking about. But imagine that vertex 1. The vertex shader needs to output a normal (that is interpolated across all faces that have this vertex 1). Which normal will it be
column13: normal[1] or normal[3]?It may work out in some specific cases
column14: where you can actually interpolate some numeric value across the faces and have it always round to a unique integer per face. Unfortunately I doubt that this has a efficient general solution. Edit: Oh
column15: and if you are thinking about Gouraud shading
column16: then that wouldn\'t work either. There you would need to output several (for each neighboring face) color values from the vertex shader. "'

column10: b'b" @whknight Alright. Let\'s recap the standard graphics pipeline a bit. Like I mentioned your regular cube would have 8 vertices. The vertex shader is ran for each of them **once**. You can pass any values from the vertex shader to the fragment shader. But they will be passed once. In your case the Normal[0:2] and Normal[9:11] are both tied to vertex0. Now you can pass one or both of those on from the vertex shader. Whichever way you do it
column11: all the neighboring faces get all the values. You see
column12: the Index array is only used to tell the GPU
column13: where are the faces (between which vertices). Ie what vertex data we read in order to create a face. I found [this illustration]url  that might help. While it is not about WebGL (which is based roughly on OpenGL 2.0)
column14: and it is also somewhat outdated
column15: the idea is the same. Vertex (element) consists of a position
column16: color
column17: normal
column18: or any other data you wish to send it. The indices specify the vertices in between which we want to interpolate values / rasterize faces. So unless there is something I\'m not aware of
column19: there is no way for two faces sharing a vertex to receive different data from it. Oh
column20: I did found something called [gl_PrimitiveID]url  but that does not seem to be available in WebGL. Regarding your idea again
column21: it seems to assume that we can pass different outputs from the vertex shader depending on the face that is currently rendered. Because the vertex shader is ran once
column22: we can\'t. For most vertices in most cases you do not want to run the vertex shader on them multiple times
column23: because the operations done and the data will be exactly the same. So currently in WebGL the only available option is still to duplicate the vertices. "'

column10: b"b' Dev Full Modularisation'"
b'b\' _Might be relevant to: #4776
column13: #7068 and #4686_## Modular Architecture Hi
column14: welcome to a funny pull request with way to many changes at once. In this case
column15: however
column16: it wasn\\\'t really possible to do it little by litte. I manually converted the whole codebase under src/ to a modular architecture and prepared a new build setup with Grunt.Some prefer Gulp over Grunt. These tools can coexist so somebody could just add a Gulp configuration later.### Build process The build process
column17: as it is now
column18: uses Grunt and Browserify with the BRFS transform to include all shader files. Glslify did not work
column19: because it broke the shader chunks by adding "#define GLSLIFY 1" to every single shader
column20: making the concatination impossible. Additionally
column21: JSHint is now integrated in the build process which helped with removing unnecessary semicolons
column22: unused variables and so on. The unit tests are executed by the Qunit plugin and Uglify generates the minified version.The examples are all working (I double checked all): url The unit tests don\\\'t work directly on the sources yet (those need to be rewritten).The math tests work if the normal three bundle is used (instead of "three-").### Changes made I noticed that there was a mix of single and double quotes and changed everything to double quotes. Furthermore
column23: I added curly brackets to all if-statements and moved variable declarations out of for-loops and if-blocks to prevent redeclarations and other potentially bad things.All constants
column24: backwards compatibility code and polyfills have been moved to seperate files.Static fields like  had to be changed to Object3
column26: etc.Every change should be backwards compatible
column27: please see  for details.WebGLShader
column28: WebGLProgram and Math were conflicting with native objects and have been renamed to _WebGLShader
column29: _WebGLProgram and _Math internally.Imports are ordered by pathname with the nearest dependencies first.### Difficulties When I first tried to run the examples with the new bundle
column30: I encountered a problem with cyclic dependencies. Cyclic dependencies are
column32: not a serious problem. The real issue arises when objects are created from classes that aren\\\'t declared yet or when a dependency short-circuits an inheritance chain. Such problems occured in Box3
column37: Shape and some other classes. The issues have been resolved for now
column38: but might need more attention. Shape inherits from Path and Path creates Shapes. The import of the Shape class in Path had to be moved inside a function. That\\\'s really bad. Luckily
column39: it only occured in Path. I named the package "@" and modified the readme file to provide basic instructions on how to use  as a module. **If you can\\\'t or don\\\'t want to adopt these changes as they are right now
column40: then that\\\'s absolutely fine.** _BTW: Since an npm package can only export one library
column41: the editor and the examples are kindof lost in space. My suggestion is to move the editor into a seperate project some day with  as its main dependency. The same could and maybe should be done with each single example. I know that this has already been asked before (#4686). Just wanted to bring it up again in the light of this modular architecture._\''
