column11: but a few questions off the top of my head. Is there any way to assure correctness? With these many changes
column12: something is bound to break. How much does the unit tests cover? How does the concatenated  file  this PR compare? You mentioned issues with cyclic dependencies. Did you consider es6 modules (using something like [rollup]url  instead of commonjs modules? ES6 modules handles cyclic dependencies and has a cleaner syntax amongst other advantages over commonjs. Not to mention that its an actual standard that will hit browsers soon. Personally
column13: I also prefer rollup to browserify for various reasons such as dead code elimination
column14: how it handles external deps etc but that isn\'t very relevant in this situation. Also

column16: I will try to look more at the actual changes tomorrow and hopefully offer some more constructive feedback then."'

ES6 modules perform much better than I thought; I did some successful testing regarding cyclic dependencies [here]url  and decided to rewrite everything to ES6 modules because that\'s simply better in the long run. column12: but I have never used Gulp before.There is no rollup Grunt plugin yet. _Should_ be easy to make. Will look into that.Cyclic dependencies are indeed handled much better by the ES6 module system. (Instantiating scratch variables inside of IIFEs still causes problems and should probably be avoided.) You\'re right
column13: the [build utils]url  will probably no longer work with this PR. However
column14: with ES6 modules it should be easy to cherrypick dependencies from the sources when using  as an npm module. For building the bundle
column15: the [include lists]url  could be moved to src/ and used by rollup as alternative entry points. I\'m very excited about this :) Converting the  sources to ES6 modules should also be easy now. May I leave this PR open until I\'m done or should I close it and open another one later?"'

column11: and have had no problems with it. Webpack or Browserify coupled with Babel does a great job. To avoid any of the problems you may have read of browsers having in this pre-es6-module era
column12: follow one simple rule: never mix named exports with default exports in the same file
column13: and you shall be fine. Under the hood
column14: Webpack and Browserify (when paired with Babel) convert ES6 modules into CommonJS modules
column15: which are the types of modules that Webpack and Browserify both use by default.'"

column10: b'b" I was expecting this PR to not get merged (see initial post bold sentence) so it\'s all good.  @GGAlanSmithee is right; it really was about showing that a modular architecture can be achieved with the current code base and dependency problems can be avoided. @futagoza Keeping a branch or parallel repo up to date is quite a challenge. Falling behind too much can mean death real quick. @mrdoob Would it be possible to consider the modularisation after the redesign of the API is done? Until then I\'ll just apply the ES6 module system for testing purposes in private and see how that goes. "'
b'b" Yep! Once API gets more stable and  all relevant browsers catch up with ES6 we\'ll start moving stuff around."'
b'b\' Here\\\'s my 2c: The term "module" is a bit loaded; switching to ES6 doesn\\\'t mean we are using _npm_ modules
column11: it just means we are using and to resolve local dependencies instead of a big concat script. Getting ThreeJS to play nicely with _npm modules_ is another challenge. Rollup is a cool idea
column12: but it is only useful to other developers also using rollup (which is a very small minority). For the UMD build I feel a more stable tool ( + Babel) would be a wiser choice
column13: and would also allow source transforms like or  .  ES6 seems like it would be easier to adopt on ThreeJS than CommonJS or another pattern. Babel supports feature blacklisting
column14: so the end result is code that is really similar to current ThreeJS
column15: but with only a few differences for and  . Over time
column16: as collaborators are more comfortable with ES6
column17: the blacklist can be relaxed. In terms of separate _npm modules_
column18: I don\\\'t think it\\\'s realistic to split ThreeJS core into many modules
column19: at least not for a long time. More likely candidates for modules: things outside of core like EffectComposer
column20: [font shapes]url  [triangulation]url  etc.\''

column10: b'b" Unfortunately not \\xe2\\x80\\x93 unless I\'m mistaken
column11: Browserify can\'t deal with ES6 natively
column12: it has to convert everything to CommonJS (e.g. with babelify). You then have the overhead of simulating the CommonJS environment (the \'prelude\' at the top of a Browserify bundle) plus the overhead of each module having its own function
column13: plus the module ID references
column14: plus the property names that are unnecessary with ES6
column15: etc
column16: etc. On top of that
column17: circular references are a giant headache with CommonJS! And Three has lots of circular references :grinning: "'

b"b' Further improvements to MeshPhysicalMaterial'"

b'b\' So here are the thigns that I noticed that can be improved on MeshPhysicalMaterial:**(UPDATE: addressed in PR #7419)** The "reflectivity" parameter should control the created specularColor within the range of 0 to 0.08 or so (I\\\'d prefer we use the upper bound of 0.18 that UE4 uses.)  If we did this we would not need to use it separately than specularColor in the SpecularLightProbe.  Remember that specularColor is F0
column11: frontal reflectivity.**(UPDATE: addressed in PR #7417)** Metalness = 1 should result in the tinting of the fresnel environment reflection to the base color -the grazing angles should be the baseColor rather than white.  Right now we are not taking into awareness of Metalness in the BRDF_Specular_GGX_Environment.  This means that metals are reflected white on grazing angles
column12: which is not physically correct. Add the ability to be energy conserving.  The standard approach is to scale down the diffuseColor by ( 1 average( specularColor ) )
column13: where specularColor is after frenel modification.**(UPDATE: addressed in PR #7421)** Need to add support for "irradiance"
column14: e.g. DiffuseLightProbe.**(UPDATE: addressed in PR #7420)** When roughness is 0
column15: the surface is not rough enough.  There is most likely a scaling bug in the code somewhere.Create a SpecularLightProbe and DiffuseLightProbe structure that includes position -this will allow for multiple to be situated in a level.**(UPDATE: addressed in PR #7414)** We probably need to use a different approach than this for the querying of the different LOD levels of the cube map as it doesn\\\'t work on a lot of devices: I understand the best way is to encode into the alpha channel the LOD level and then use that to bias up or down as necessary.  It requires two queries but it should work on all devices that use cube maps.We are relying upon seamless cubemaps
column16: but actually that is against the WebGL 1.0 spec.  We should probably figure out a way to filter the cubemaps.  I know @WestLangley was looking into this.  could be a solution for the irradiance cubeMaps as well.  I created a bug for the PMREM generator here: url \''

column10: b'b" Would it be a good idea to use @tschw\'s that shadows use? url "'
b"b' I should have been more specific
column11: the issue is with the automatically generated CubeMap LOD levels.  WebGL 2.x and OpenGL ES 3.x require them to be generated seamlessly
column12: but in WebGL 2.0 and OpenGL EX 2.x the spec says that they are not seamless.  But strangely
column13: ANGLE does seamless CubeMap LOD generation
column14: so I wrote the above code that relies on this
column15: but it is out of spec behavior.  We should use a spec-based method.  More details:  url '"

column10: b"b' No problem to filter seamlessly when filtering in software... Single-image cubemaps may also give better performance when generating the LOD levels.Still there are no guaranteed filters for automatic mipmap generation which can be a problem when using them for roughness. There is a recommendation to use box filters
column11: IIRC
column12: but Gaussians happened to look much nicer for me. So even with WebGL 2 we may want to generate the LOD levels manually. ![materials_metals]url '"

column10: b'b" We should always generate the LOD levels manually if possible using proper filters
column11: the auto-generated stuff actually looks pretty horrible and we need a filter for irradiance mapping anyhow. :) I\'ve seen people also only generate 4 LOD levels as well
column12: rather than a full set.  I\'m not attached to cubemaps or single image textures. The only complication is if you want to use a live specular light probe.  UE4 does this.  This requires fast filtering and maybe necessary to use HW cube map generation or we can just not do LOD and use it only for sharp specular reflections."'

column10: b"b' Diffuse indirect environment light'"

b"b' This builds upon the cosine specular LOD filtering PR: #7414  In this PR I add the calculation of indirect diffuse from the environment map.  This is done by querying the lowest level of the environment map in the normal direction (as opposed to the specular reflection direction) and accumulating it in the indirect diffuse section in the lights_.'"

column10: b"b' We should likely support both SH and cubemap-based irradiance
column11: the reason is SH is a bit hard to compute real-time and it takes a ton of uniform space
column12: where as we can fit a cubemap irradiance map into the last part of a specular pre-convolved cubemap MIP change (either the automatic ones or the cubeToUV2 format
column13: thus taking no additional uniforms at all -also it means we can generate them real-time in the same framework. I have found that 16x16x6 cubemaps or 32x32x6 cubemaps look great for irradiance.'"

column10: b"b' @tschw No worries
column11: I understand being busy. BTW I think that just doing a simple prefilter manually would be sufficient to avoid the lack of seamless cubemaps.  Just a filter that is equivalent to the automatic cubemap filtering combined with cubeToUv2 would be better than our system in all ways -it would now longer need the cubeMapLodExt (so it works on all devices) and it would also not require seamless cubemap filtering (so we do not see seams.) Getting all of the other math right is sort of a separate issue
column12: or I would suggest treating it as one to keep everything tractable.  We can perfect the BRDFs and swap out a sampler in the cubemap generator later -and we likely will have to create multiple samplers and BRDFs that go with them to support multiple different models as we go forward.'"

b'b" I\'d like to share a problem I encountered today about WebGLState. There are at least two ways to  some states. For exemple
column11: it\'s possible to disable blending with these two lines : and A conflict can occurs because only the first one is based on an internal saved state (called  ) . So
column12: if you enable blending with the second way
column13: the first one won\'t be able to disable it I know OpenGL state is something to carefully change but  shouldn\'t add additional complexity to it."'

column10: b"b' How do you think it should be?'"
b"b' Also
column11: can you please explain your use case? What is your need for manipulating the renderer state from the application level?'"

column10: b'b\' ### My use case I am creating a SSAO effect on a scene which has shadow mapping (based on your implementation) and some HUD. Typically
column11: I have different kinds of render passes: depth map from light (for shadow mapping)depth map from scene camera (for ssao)ssao map from depth map (for ssao)a scene to the screen viewporta quad render in front of the screen which adds my blurred ssao effect with blendingsome quad render in front of screen viewport to make HUD Note : I didn\\\'t use or something based on that because of antialiasing. So
column12: I have to manage several renderings
column13: several kinds of rendering
column14: several OpenGL states like blending or face culling for example. **How I encountered what I described yesterday ?**  I wanted to be sure of which OpenGL state is enabled or not without reading through each  codeline. So I decided to manually enable blending before my post process rendering
column15: then disable it before my HUDs rendering and finally enable it at the end because it\\\'s its default state. Note: you can solve the associated problem by a full understanding of what happens and a full management of your GL state (what I prefer and what I\\\'ve done) or you can reset your GL state w\\xc3\\xacth  . But there is still something not very logical with the API. ### An example This is a basic scene: [url  ![url  This is the same scene with a simple post processing effect and a HUD: [url  ![url  This is what I wanted: [url  ![url  You\\\'re going to tell me that I don\\\'t need to add any blending management to make it work and you\\\'ll be right :-) But I couldn\\\'t know it and I didn\\\'t do anything illogical. In fact
column16: I\\\'ve just enabled blending before my second render call (which will actually enable it by itself) and I  blending for the third call which should globally be ineffective. It should globally be ineffective because there is no blending stuff in this third scene. Especially
column17: the  render function will call : which is consistant with my disable call
column18: and my enable call is consistant with to the default state :  **What is the problem ?**  Like I said before
column19: there are two not equivalent ways to disable some GL state like blending at least. In details
column20: at the end of the first "animate" call the GL blend state is enable by and the WebGLState param is still equal to  . From the second "animate" call
column21: the first render pass will try to disable the blending by (see above) but that will fail because the blending is already disabled from the WebGLState object point of view. So
column22: the opaque sphere is badly rendered. I know it\\\'s tricky and it\\\'s why I take my time to code a typical example and explain how and why ;-) ### How it should be From my point of view
column23: the most important thing is to be consistent in the API. There are different solutions which are opinionated
column24: it\\\'s why I think the decision is yours.1. You could not check the current state of blending ( ) and directly set GL stuff every time it\\\'s asked. I can\\\'t suggest you should do that because I don\\\'t know the cost of GL change between rendering passes and I think you\\\'ve done what you\\\'ve done for a reason.2. You could always check the current value of each GL state before setting it in an unique way. It\\\'s a little bit painful...3. Like 2. you could only check the current value of each GL state which can be set in a different way : blending
column25: depth function
column26: depth write
column27: ...4. You could warn users to use specific functions for some GL state like blending. In this case
column28: I suggest you clean up some code like in to not make users confused. Ty for reading =D\''

column10: b'b" Another way to solve the issue would be making set to  . But it\'s sneaky and could potentially cause more problems..."'
b"b' A PR would be most welcome!'"
b"b' Any PR that prevents the user from placing the renderer into an invalid state is fine with me. The renderer needs to maintain tight control over its own state.'"
b'b" I\'ll do some PR ;)"'
b'b\' More generally
column11: as long as is public it\\\'s possible to change any GL state and make "invalid". Each private variable can be out of sync with its associated GL value. Moreover
column12: has its own private checking with which add another layer of complexity and another possibility of invalidity through a direct access. So
column13: before doing something I would like to know if you want to only focus on state and how it manages itself or if you want to fully sync with true GL states ?\''

column10: b'b" @looeee I agree that\'s what I\'m saying -sorry if I was unclear. The material attributes would have to be written to a target so they can be sampled in screen space and used to fade or blur the reflections at the given pixel. This would allow roughness maps etc to affect the reflections
column11: as well."'

column10: b'b" I would love to see this become part of  default capabilities. There\'s a lot of stuff like this that makes you wonder whether a deferred renderer architecture should also become part of the default offering. Especially for webgl2.0"'
b'b" @gkjohnson got it
column11: that makes sense. However
column12: it still seems like a mask of some kind might be neccessary to prevent artefacts. In your example
column13: you would want zero reflections on the drapes and plants. Would fading to zero based on those material\'s properties work correctly? "'

column10: b'b\' @bicubic  I agree I\\\'d really like to see a dedicated deferred rendering path
column11: as well. With WebGL2 and multiple render textures it\\\'s much more viable.  @looee It depends on the effect you want but with the approach I described the rendered roughness value would effectively behave as the mask for the scene with a roughness value of 1 meaning "render no reflection at this pixel" and a value of 0 meaning "render full reflection at this pixel". Values in between would render reflections at a partial intensity. The slider in the demo shows the effect (but obviously for the whole scene instead of per pixel).  Another approach is to blur the reflected pixels based on the roughness value to emulate a diffuse surface reflecting light. So the drapes would still have some reflections
column12: just not sharp ones. This would allow for the drape being illuminated by a brightly lit blue floor
column13: for example.\''

column10: b'b\'  Seems like this could work well. [Unreal uses a "max roughness" parameter]url  and reccommends it be set to 0.8.\''

column10: b'b" I\'ve integrated it now
column11: while the SSR pass outputs to a lower resolution RT
column12: basically only the reflections and then combine it using a depth blur with the main image to  the errors. I render the roughness values to an attributes RT and use it again to determine the strength of blur with 1 being invisible to discard the fragment.  The blur also removes the error which gets stronger in distance. One issue yet seems to be transparency again and objects partially covering others causing to clip the others reflection. I really need to read more about the technique. ![c1]url  ![c2]url I\'m using it with a custom engine on top on THREE
column13: not using the compositor of THREE. THREE is actually ready to use a WebGL2 context in the current WebGLRenderer
column14: i\'ve added the MRT there. I\'ll put it on github soon i guess. It still requires to render the scene a second time for the backface depth buffer though
column15: but that isn\'t too expensive. "'

column10: b'b" Could this be some load order thing. I seem to get this more if I disable network cache in the Chrome dev tools network tab. If you disable it it is more likely to happen. I\'m using this page to test url  The texture has a  . If cache is enabled
column11: you\'ll get a quick 304 or directly using from cache (inside that 10mins
column12: this can vary on Chrome thinks you are doing
column13: if it will check 304 or not). When its returned from cache it\'s more likely the texture is already there before next render is called and you wont get this warning. I can repro getting the black texture more often and those warnings if I disable cache (though not every time). This could be some kind of timing issue. The OBJLoader is doing this url So when it it not read quickly from cache the material is initialized in render before the texture is in place. Futhermore our app loads the textures to the material fully before its set to any meshes. Hence they will be initialized in render() only when textures are in place. It looks like we dont get these warnings even if cache is disabled. Some code that does not follow this pattern did produce the warnings :P Just my 2 cents. Might be something that happens if is set after the first material init. **Edit:** Sometimes with cache disabled you can see the black texture there for a moment
column14: then get few of those warnings
column15: then the real texture is updated. Most times the last step is not done and you end up with black."'

column10: b'b\' This console log from the above when cache is disabled I think is helpful: This is a run where it was black (2x + 26x render() calls)
column11: but then loaded the texture and it stopped printing warnings. Usually WebGL says "too many warnings
column12: no more will be printed"
column13: but this run it stopped because the cause of the warning went away. If that makes sense. Looks to me like its related to using materials with unfinished (null texture units) texture loads in them. Then afterwards updating the texture and  .\''

I\'ve noticed there is an  property but couldn\'t find an obvious way to set it only for objects

Having complex scene the one could want to check if depth prepass would give him performance boost without spending time in renderer code. And it is probably not worth trying due to extra frustum culling cost. Sorry if I missed something."'

column10: b'b\' Right
column11: it was something like that.  Now I\\\'m not sure that this optimization should be in core since it complicates code base and is very situational
column12: that is why I closed PR. If someone needs this optimization he indeed could tinker it in renderer or at app level (with some overhead).  However
column13: performance boost from depth prepass comes in case of "complex per-fragment computations in a scene
column14: where effective objects sorting couldn\\\'t be performed". It makes sure that unneeded computations in fragment shader wouldn\\\'t be performed for opaque objects (like with early z-test
column15: which is not guaranteed) at cost of extra render pass with depth materials.\''

column10: b"b' @WestLangley @mrdoob This was actually a really good idea.  Depth-prepasses are used by all modern games
column11: such as Doom
column12: Metal Gear Solid V
column13: etc.'"

column10: b"b' I think we just need more context. What would be a use case for a core material to use this? '"
b'b" The idea is that before you render your opaque beauty pass (which is costly on a per-pixel basis)
column11: you render the depth pre-pass
column12: which is a fast to run material and it just fills the z-buffer.  Then when you run the opaque beauty pass
column13: no pixels that are hidden are every written because you have pre-populated the z-buffer.  You need to render the beauty pass with EQUAL rather than LESS THAN
column14: but given you are just re-rendering the same faces with the same values
column15: it will not produce artifacts/z-fighting.  This is useful when there is lots of complex geometry that leads to costly overdraw.  If you just have a single sphere
column16: this doesn\'t help.  But if you have lots of complex large shapes that hide each other (think indoors with walls
column17: etc)
column18: this can save between 30% to 50% of beauty pixel computations."'

column10: b"b' I think this can be implemented as a DepthPrePass in the composer maybe.  Rather than the way it was in this specific PR.'"

column11: I see. Yeah
column12: for objects with a lot of "self overdraw". Indeed. It seems simple enough though. I think it\\\'s more of a matter of repurposing the ShadowMap code instead of duplicating.\''

b"b' Script to auto-format all regions of code that a feature branch modifies'"
b'b" This PR introduces a new script
column11: that applies an auto-formatter script to just the regions of files that you have modified between your current branch and  .  The formatter script uses both and to get your code as much inline with the mrdoobapproves style as possible. To use the script
column12: do the following: 1) ensure you have committed all changes2) run  3) (hope it doesn\'t give you an error ;) )4) view formatting changes as unstaged modifications to your files5) correct any  fixes6) commit You should only see changes to regions of files that you have actually touched in your branch (it may bleed a line or two into neighboring regions due to how diff splits chunks). The goal of this approach is:1) provide folks with an automated way to apply code formatting to their changes2) prevent PR\'s that modify huge parts of the code base for the sake of styling3) help ensure that new changes abide by the style guide4) try and enforce more rules than the mrdoobapproves webtool is able to manage."'

column10: b'b" It may be useful. I myself like to format the code myself. But OTOH we get submissions that are stylistically off
column11: and it may save some work. However
column12: I\'m not so fond about changing the entire code base. If we do it
column13: it must be done piecemeal not to cause major breakage of pending PRs. Also
column14: I\'d like to see common sense put over strict enforcement of rules in that case. Maybe the tool should only add whitespace and never remove it? The primary goal of a style guide is to have source code read good in a consistent fashion
column15: where readability is far more important than strict consistency
column16: especially in cases where the latter goal compromises the former. Horizontal alignment is useful to make code more readable. As long as the style guide doesn\'t explicitly forbid it
column17: I think it should be left alone. Line breaks are a similar issue. Looking at professional typesetting software like TeX
column18: it takes quite an effort to automate line breaks so that they look aesthetic to the reader."'

One interesting way to use the tool would be: 1) run on your modified source files2) run on files modified in your index to "approve" each change made by the formatter (allowing you to reject the few cases where the formatter does not do the right thing) Outstanding issues I have not figured out yet (you can see these issues if you run the test runner script):arrays whose elements are "right-aligned" seem to have their trailing whitespace modifiedblock comments are not made prettierthere\\\'s not really a good way to "correct" bad  names.  also no way to distinguish between a function used as a function vs. a class.  lines beginning with a comma are not modified in a great waycannot remove statement from default switch case Here is an example from the test runner showing current issues with expression formatting.  You can see that an indent that should have been kept was not

column10: b'b\' I think that running the formatter "only on modified" lines is trickier than it sounds.  These formatters are analyzing the code in a way such that they can build a full syntax tree to analyze.  If you only submitted a portion of your sourcefile as input to the tools they would have a different tree and thus format the code differently (i.e. different amounts of indentation
column11: etc.) But you could use the diff between dev and the feature to determine which  of the formatted results should be accepted or not.  \''

column13: but perhaps just come up w/ a script to format the modified lines
column14: and add the formatting changes as a separate commit
column15: and have running the script be part of the guidelines for contributing changes."'

column10: b'b\' Scripts are going into the right direction
column11: but I think they should become easier to use. Actually
column12: the correct algorithm is to look through of both and the feature branch and figure out the first commit ID both have in common. This is the state you want to diff against and should be the default behavior without any options given
column13: so the script "just works". Anything else will get very confusing for the casual user when is pulled up
column14: and there will be many false positives. You can take an option to let the user specify another branch than
column15: which is useful when you have branches that depend on one another
column16: but I guess that goes under "nice to have". As long as there are formatting issues like the ones you describe (and maybe there always will be)
column17: I think it\\\'s crucial that only lines that are actually edited are being formatted. Otherwise a single change to a file may easily cause quite a mess (e.g. when the user gets confused by the patched add
column18: which is fairly likely to happen :) ). Instead
column19: you can create a reverse patch once the script has applied its changes
column20: remove all lines that have been changed and apply it
column21: so everything outside the edited region is reverted before the commit. Recipe:1. check that all changes are properly checked in
column22: abort if not2. get logs of the feature branch and the base branch (  by default)3. figure out first common commit id in both logs
column23: let\\\'s call it base-ref4. diff against base-ref and figure out all files / lines that have been changed5. run the formatter on the files that have been changed6. reverse diff against head7. remove all lines that were changed (according to the first diff)8. patch to revert changes outside the edited region9. add all files that were changed & commit\''

column10: b'b\' @tschw  I definitely would want to clean up the scripts to be user-friendly.  I\\\'m trying to first sketch out the key aspects of the process. I think that your git log approach is covered by simply using the name of your branch as the pointer to the current commit and the latest commit on dev (provided you have pulled the latest from ). column10: b'b" @tschw for some reason
column11: when I limited the diff to zero extra lines of context around the changed lines
column12: the resulting filtered diff was failing when I tried to apply it.  Adding 1 line of extra context solved the problem.  This is essentially what happens.  I figure out which files are changed between dev and the feature.  I then run the formatter over the entire files for that list.  I generate a diff patch (using  ) of the formatting step w/ the previous commit.  I then filter that diff patch to just the regions that were touched by the feature branch.  I then revert the full formatting changes and then apply the filtered diff.  Perhaps I miscommunicated? I\'m sure that this tool could be tweaked and fine-tuned ad nauseum
column13: however
column14: I can\'t honestly say I\'m very interested in taking it much further.  This idea has turned into quite a project that
column15: when compared to other features

column17: great.  If others are interested in adding to this
column18: fantastic.  If it will require hours more work
column19: I can\'t say I\'m interested
column20: and would rather just close this.  "'

column12: I\'m still in support for merging the code. @abelnation Why does filtering have to happen at chunk level? And why is context being processed? AFAICT
column13: an edit within a diff is undone by simply changing the deleting lines to context and removing the re-adding ones. If because the formatter messes with line breaks

column15: I believe it\'s still doable although admittedly trickier to get the filtering right :)."'

column10: b'b" @tschw I suppose I\'m trying to balance effectiveness for simplicity of execution.  The output of consists of chunks that differ
column11: e.g. a range of line numbers followed by the lines changed.  I could get more involved and literally rewrite the diff (e.g. to modify the line number ranges as I modify which line modifications are included)
column12: but it just feels like an uneven complexity / value ratio. I also worry about how to filter diff output within the individual chunks.  Currently
column13: I filter the diff output on a per-chunk basis
column14: which is fairly straightforward and without edge cases.  Once you start mucking w/ the actual content of each chunk
column15: you get into all sorts of complexity wrt which lines to
column16: how to modify the line ranges etc.  "'

column10: b"b'  does not support area lights (yet). Hemisphere lights in  are a source of indirect diffuse (ambient) light which is only reflected diffusely. Pure metals have no diffuse component -they only reflect specularly. The code is working properly.  is best used with an environment map if is non-zero -for exactly the reason above.Diffusely reflected light from an environment map is currently only computed for cube maps.'"

column10: b'b" @thmasn you are correct that in the case of an hemisphere light
column11: we should have our metallic materials reflecting that light.  It shouldn\'t be necessary to create a texture to represent them.  This is just something that needs to be fixed in ThreeJS properly.  Thanks for bringing this up."'

column10: b'b" Here is an implementation of a hemisphere light that supports specular I haven\'t validated its correctness though: url "'
b"b' @bhouston As  is currently implemented
column11: a encodes irradiance
column12: which is the total energy received over the hemisphere defined by the surface normal. That is why it adds to indirect diffuse. An encodes the same thing -it is just a constant  . Neither are physically-based
column13: because they apply to just the diffuse component -to the exclusion of the specular one. For a specular reflection
column14: you need to have something to reflect. A hemisphere light does not provide anything to reflect. Nor does an ambient light. (Why? Because they encode irradiance only -not radiance.) We have two choices if you want to have a consistent model.1. Physical material should not support and  . Users should specify a light probe (environment map) instead.2. We modify and so they produce the same result as a light probe with the upper hemisphere of one color and the lower hemisphere of the second (or same) color. I have found that specular reflection on metals in which the light source is constant everywhere does not look good. However
column15: if you are happy with the look of option 2
column16: then that is fine. If you are not
column17: then only option 1 makes sense. I am willing to go either route.'"

column10: b"b' Hemispheric lights are popular in rendering so I think we need to for #2.  I do not think it should be a hard change to make
column11: we just need to ensure that the units for specular make sense compared to the irradiance for diffuse.  I will not have time for this this week though
column12: but I think the derivation is actually very easy
column13: probably just multiply irradiance by the right constant.'"

column10: b'b\' @bhouston Granted. The units are not a concern to me right now -it is what to reflect. We have to specify something to reflect... Question: So the way you want to think about it is that when a user specifies a
column11: we think of it as "short-hand" for specifying an IBL with 2 colors -top and bottom? Any idea how to handle the blurring part? Maybe we have to actually construct an IBL cube map internally
column12: then everything will just work. We can create new classes that do just that:

column10: b"b' We could just view it as a sphere with an upper half of one color and a lower half of another color as the OP suggested.  I believe that the existing diffuse hemispheric light is based on approximating the hemispheric contributions from a two halved light like that.  We could likely check that approximation and fix it if it diverges significantly.  Thus we would just fix our light by minimally changing it to match a physical one as the OP suggests.'"

column12: then you can write your own method that recomputes normals on a sub-range of _vertices_.'"

column10: b'b" @kpetrow saidYou can. You need to know the indices of those vertices. In your case
column11: your geometry is a plane
column12: so you can likely determine the indices of the neighboring vertices. @makc saidWhy does what matter? For non-indexed-bufferGeometry
column13: the buffer contains vertices in groups of three. So if one vertex is changed
column14: the other two vertices of the face are easily located in the buffer. On the other hand
column15: if you displace a vertex in a solid mesh and the mesh\'s geometry is non-indexed
column16: you will have tearing unless you are able to concurrently displace all coincident vertices by the same amount."'

column10: b'b" Hi
column11: I encountered a similar problem a while ago.That\'s because you kept the other files of Three a secret from Rollup. If you import from the entry file
column12: Rollup will be aware of all the other existing files of which quite many contain certain statements that may have side-effects. The tree-shaking mechanism is rather conservative and statements such as will make it fail immediately
column13: resulting in the inclusion of the file it occured in. A related Rollup discussion: url "'

column10: b"b' also
column11: it makes sense that the import yields an output that is a lot smaller since that class only depends on: So as long as we get the bundle working
column12: we can start optimiznig away things that prevents treeshaking
column13: and if possible reduce coupling between modules.'"

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: but Rollup has to process the export catalog to reach the desired dependency and that alone exposes the other files to the bundler. Apparently
column12: Rollup can\'t easily determine whether the immediate instantiation of inside the iife is side-effect-free. _The tree-shaking bails out fast_
column13: probably for bundling-performance reasons. If the instantiation is inside a function declaration
column14: it\'s considered safe. The bewildering thing about this is that gets included in the final bundle although it\'s not used by  . In my opinion
column15: the unrelated file shouldn\'t even be visited by Rollup
column16: but
column17: _to be safe_
column18: it does just that and includes it regardless because of the questionable instantiation.As far as I know
column19: improving the logic for side-effect detection hasn\'t been the development focus of Rollup thus far. I can imagine that the current behaviour is due to performance considerations."'

b"b' Allow user to abort all active requests managed by a LoadingManager.'"

b"b' I needed this functionality and I think others will find it useful too. The possibility to abort can also be implemented just for a request ( The active request of a Loader). To accomplish this I was thinking about keeping a reference to the current XMLHttpRequest. Here is an example with React:  '"

b'b" There was also an inconsistency inside ImageLoader. It didn\'t pass its loading manager ( ) to the XHRLoader created inside the load method. So the ImageLoader was calling the **itemStart** and **itemEnd** methods of its loading manager and the XHRLoader was calling the **itemStart** and **itemEnd** methods of the DefaultLoadingManager for the same call of the **load** method of the ImageLoader."'
b"b' I suspect this change has side effects. It tends to be better to keep PR simple and on topic.'"
b'b" I don\'t see what side effects it can have. The other loaders that use XHRLoader pass the loading manager. They let the XHRLoader call **itemStart**
column11: **itemEnd** and **itemError** methods. Now if the load method of an ImageLoader is called these methods are called twice. This was on topic. It\'s not possible to elegantly abort all active requests with two LoadingManagers ( DefaultLoadingManager always used by XHRLoader when created by ImageLoader and the one passed to the ImageLoader). I think the PR is simple
column12: just a few lines of code were modified."'

column10: b"b' within this particular manager
column11: right? not all requests in application?'"

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: a loading manager can abort its active requests. Usually you don\'t use many loading managers in one application
column12: but I\'m open to suggestions. What do you think about the proposed solution to abort a single request (the current one of a loader)?"'

column10: b'b" Hmm
column11: this  /  is a real pain as the renderer has no idea what the side-effects are of those callbacks
column12: which is extremely harmful to the renderer\'s ability to optimise rendering. The way dynamic uniforms were implemented probably wasn\'t as intuitive as it could have been
column13: but at least the renderer knew if it encountered an object with dynamic uniforms then then that object must be excluded from any internal optimisations the renderer implements. Setting and to have a default function rather than being is particularly harmful. As it\'s now totally impossible for the renderer to know which objects are going to be messing with the renderer\'s state. I\'m going to submit a pull request soon that provides _enormous_ performance gains for a lot of scenes. I was just rebasing it on and ran into this. At the very least my pull request will revert the default empty function assignment
column14: I\'ll leave the rest open to discussion when the pull request drops."'

column10: b"b' How is this handled by game engines? '"
b'b\' Game engines typically don\\\'t expose low level systems like uniforms to high level systems like the the scene graph
column11: at least not without one or more abstraction layers. This is extremely important for game engines as they\\\'re typically cross-platform and support multiple renderers (rendering details are hidden away). Callbacks also aren\\\'t typically called per
column12: they\\\'re called per controller (MVC)
column13: where the "view" is a "node"
column14: or in threejs\\\' case an
column15: and the controller is responsible for updating the node. \''

column10: b"b' Specular strength is either a measure of Fresnel Reflectance at F0 (we implemented this in the physical material as reflectance) or it is a measure of glossiness (e.g. roughness.)  Either way
column11: specular strength should not have the capability of reducing Fresnel at the rim to nothing
column12: thus if it is behaving this way in this PR or elsewhere it is a bug.  Fresnel is always present in physically based models.  You do not get to remove it and still be a physically based model -you are purposely trying to create a special effect that is non-physical.  See this page here for more: url '"

column10: b"b' Discussed a bit more in that issue but then this comes down to a modulating parameter for the modulating textures. @bhouston'"
b'b\' Just to clarify this pull request was scoped purely mimicking a texture slot with a constant texture. If someone wants to put a "roughness" texture that is all gray
column11: black or white
column12: for any reason
column13: this suggestion should make it easier. It should be agnostic of what @bhouston is talking about. I.e. here in particular it\\\'s one parameter that was discussed in the linked issue. What that parameter does
column14: and if it breaks PBR or the universe
column15: is not relevant here. What is relevant is that there was a texture parameter
column16: and that someone was using textures filled with one constant color. This should make doing that easier. No need to go into photoshop
column17: modify the textures
column18: just assign the value you would otherwise save to that texture. This pr does not modify the lighting equations in any way. GLSL wise
column19: it only hooks another uniform which is already in full control by the user. \''

column11: here are some related info & issues:  * I reported a similar issue on @donmccurdy\'s ThreeJS glTF viewer
column12: -gltf-viewer#10.  But I now think this is a bug in ThreeJS\'s glTF loader
column13: not in the viewer.  So
column14: this new issue is better placed than my old issue.  * In the above older issue
column15: the model used to face the sky
column16: but later I rotated it to face the horizon.  This makes it easier to see when the reflections aren\'t right
column17: because the horizon rotates around crazily
column18: as shown above.  * The model\'s own use of a normal map was confirmed correct by discussion in #952.  * ThreeJS\'s handling of normal maps was questioned in #11315.  * BabylonJS recently had a similar problem

column10: b'b" I wasn\'t aware of #15749 until now.  I\'m caught off guard by this
column11: I had thought we did a good enough job defining the tangents in glTF that they could be at least approximated at runtime.  Note that the Blender exporter won\'t export any glTF tangents by default
column12: as it helps keep the file size down
column13: and the major implementations of glTF were all passing this test without tangents.  I suspect this change may have broken normal mapping for a majority of glTF models in ThreeJS.  I\'ll need some time to read through all the linked issues to get a deeper understanding of what\'s happened and why.  But I think the glTF community should consider this high priority to get models without tangents rendering correctly again
column14: as I believe most models are in that category by default."'

column10: b"b' Reopening \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x85'"
b'b\'  I don\\\'t believe it\\\'s anything that severe \\xe2\\x80\\x93 we\\\'ve always generated tangents realtime in the shader with derivatives
column11: and we still do. We previously included a hack ( ) that happened to fix this specific test model
column12: but also happened to break some other examples.  I have no explanation for when that helped
column13: or didn\\\'t
column14: so we removed the hack once we supported stored tangents \\xe2\\x80\\x93 in which case it would certainly have been wrong. Now the models that relied on the hack (and don\\\'t include tangents) are broken
column15: and models that were broken by the hack (and don\\\'t include tangents) are fixed. See above. In general
column16: I believe we do render models without tangents adequately. We do not
column17: however
column18: generate mikktspace tangents as required by the glTF spec. To my knowledge
column19: no JS implementation of that exists
column20: and our derivatives-based shader implementation is simply a "mostly good enough" approximation. This sample model is an intentionally extreme case that demonstrates the limits of that approximation.  We\\\'d be glad to have a JS mikktspace tangent generation implementation; that would be good addition to . But the official (native) mikktspace code is fairly long
column21: and I haven\\\'t dug in enough yet to see how much of that is required for generating tangents.\''

column10: b'b\'  Did it break other glTF models specifically
column11: or just examples in general?  There are two different types of tangent-space normal maps out in the wild.  Substance Painter calls these "DirectX Normals" and "OpenGL Normals"
column12: which is not the greatest name for it.  The difference is specifically the channel is inverted
column13: meaning all of the green channel values in the texture are inverted.  Multiplying is the correct way to convert one to the other.  The so-called "DirectX Normals" use a left-handed coordinate system
column14: and glTF defines a right-handed coordinate system for .  What I suspect is happening is that when ThreeJS auto-calculates tangents
column15: it expects the normal map to have been authored with the flipped Y (DirectX) style
column16: and gets that channel backwards for glTF
column17: so the flip is needed.  However
column18: when the tangents are supplied
column19: no such flip is needed.  The question of mikktspace I think is separate from this.  It\\\'s unfortunate that the spec calls for mikktspace and most implementations approximate that with screen-space derivatives.  I don\\\'t know how similar the two are
column20: but
column21: normal maps generated in mikktspace appear to work reasonably well when shown with the approximation
column22: so long as the -handedness of the map is done correctly.  (There\\\'s also some discussion of this from last year in -Sample-Models#174)\''

column10: b'b" I\'d like to call out one sentence from the [glTF spec on normal maps]url  in particular: This sentence is what allows models to be shipped without tangent vectors
column11: saving space.  Let\'s test it.  Here I\'ve made a lousy height map (bump map) out of a splotch in a paint program:  ![TestHeightMap]url Let\'s define this height field as an outward bump
column12: where white pixels are closer to the viewer
column13: and black pixels are further away.  Using an online converter (of questionable quality
column14: but we\'ll examine the result in a moment)
column15: I\'ve converted this from a height map to a normal map.  Keep in mind there\'s no 3D model here
column16: no UV coordinates or mikktspace calculations or any geometry.  Just a height map converted to a normal map.  I had to manually configure the online converter per glTF\'s instructions
column17: such that X is right
column18: Y is up
column19: and Z faces the viewer.  This is the result:  ![TestNormalMap]url Let\'s bring that back into a paint program and bust out the color channels to see where these vectors point.  Below
column20: each color channel has been separated into a grayscale image of its own.  Remember that these will be interpreted such that black means
column21: middle gray means
column22: and white means  .  ![TestNormalMap-Decomposed]url So I think the online converter did what glTF asked
column23: at least after configuring it correctly.  In the Red (X) image
column24: we can see the slope on the right has white pixels (+1.0)
column25: pointing the X vector at the right edge of the image.  On the left side of the Red image
column26: black pixels (-1.0) point the X vector at the left side of the image.  In the Green (Y) image
column27: white pixels along the top slope of the bump point the Y vector at the top of the image.  The Z values are the least intuitive
column28: but remember that the tip of the bump and the back plate itself both point at the viewer
column29: and the slopes on all sides point away
column30: so are all evenly darker.  What if we load this into Blender Eevee
column31: which (just like glTF) accepts OpenGL-style normal maps?  What happens if the UV map is rotated
column32: or even scaled to be inverted?  ![NormalSpinTest]url Turns out
column34: the whole point of defining the tangent space this way is not to enable software to go crazy with the vectors
column35: it\'s to allow texture artists some sanity by ensuring that their normal maps will be right-side up regardless of the geometry.  But
column36: not all software uses the OpenGL convention.  Some uses a different convention (sometimes called the DirectX convention)
column37: where the Y vectors point at the bottom of the image instead of the top.  Here\'s the decomposed Y channel of my image in this form.  The lighter pixels are the ones facing the bottom of the image.  ![TestNormalMap_DirectX-Green]url If I load one of these DirectX-style normal maps into Blender Eevee
column38: can I still expect it to work?  ![NormalSpinTest_DirectX_v3]url No.  Blender was expecting +Y up.  The math is wrong
column39: and the reflected horizon line spins all around.  The same thing happens if you load an OpenGL-style normal map into an engine that was expecting +Y down.  This is what the NormalTangentTest model is attempting to test.  Each row spins the UV coordinates into a different orientation
column40: trying to make sure that the reflections remain right-side up in these different orientations. "'

column10: b'b\' There still needs to be a concrete formula in the specification for how to compute a tangent for a lone primitive
column11: given a primitive and its UV coordinates
column12: and which W sign to use for bitangent. "OpenGL normals" and "DX normals" is not precise enough to derive the formula. They might refer to conventions
column13: but I have no idea as an implementer what to do with that.  What I currently do is emit flipped TangentW from MikkTSpace to match up with this particular sample
column14: but that was just what happened to work.\''

column10: b'b\'  Reported bugs were related to glTF models
column11: specifically. That said
column12: I doubt there\\\'s enough confidence in material export via FBX or COLLADA to say those normal map conventions were ever thoroughly understood and tested either. Thanks
column13: this is a much better justification of our "hack" than we had when we implemented it. \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x87 The spec is right that MikkTSpace is the most robust way to generate tangents
column14: I think
column15: it\\\'s just not universally the right choice to do this automatically at runtime. If cheaper alternatives look correct for a particular model
column16: there\\\'s no reason to do something more expensive that doesn\\\'t look any better. The spec language could be loosened to allow for approximations but I don\\\'t feel strongly about this. I\\\'m not sure the MikkTSpace algorithm is so easy to represent as a discrete formula... are you asking for an alternative to the canonical MikkTSpace code? Or some additional information beyond the instruction to use MikkTSpace?  @Themaister ***  For the original issue
column17: it sounds like we ought to restore the multiplier somewhere. There are three possible places to do this:  (a) in GLTFLoader
column18: for meshes that do not have tangents (b) in GLTFLoader
column19: for all meshes (c) in WebGLRenderer
column20: for all meshes  If threejs is really using the DirectX convention and e.g. Blender is not
column21: I could see a case for (c). In the interest of a quick and safe solution
column22: though
column23: I am inclined to go with (a).\''

column10: b'b\' >What I suspect is happening is that when ThreeJS auto-calculates tangents
column11: it expects the normal map to have been authored with the flipped Y (DirectX) style.  No
column12: does not assume that...  assumes +Y is "up" for tangent space
column13: and increasing-V is "up" for uv space.  That is
column14: assumes uv ( 0
column15: 0 ) is in the lower-left corner of the texture
column16: while the glTF spec assumes the upper-left. This is why sets to  .  ( sets to  by default.)  When tangents are not present
column17: uses screen-space derivatives to estimate tangents. It does so using the chain rule. An assumption in that calculation is that tangent space and uv space have the same orientation.  For properly-authored glTF models
column18: that assumption is not correct. However
column19: you should be able to compensate by setting for any model that _properly adheres to the glTF spec_.  It would also seem to me we could fix this automatically by honoring the flag in the shader.  If setting is not working
column20: then something else is going on. \''

column10: b'b" Thanks for this clarification.  I think we have a path forward here. Yes
column11: with the exception of cases where the glTF supplies its own tangent vectors
column12: right?  I would expect only the auto-computed tangents to need the test and corresponding negation of  .  ~~If that\'s not the case... that would mean that my model has incorrect tangents encoded into it
column13: meaning the Blender glTF exporter itself is putting the wrong tangents into glTF models.  Blender is using a lower-left origin
column14: and off the top of my head I don\'t know if that means the tangent vectors themselves must be edited or not before copying into the model (and whether the exporter performs such edits).~~  Edit: I believe I\'ve confirmed the correctness of the exported tangent vectors
column15: and they do not need any Y flipping.  I can post more detail on that if needed.  But it seems like the correct action is to flip only when auto-generated tangents (not supplied tangents) are being used with the flag.  Thoughts?"'

column10: b'b" In my previous post
column11: I explained how to manually compensate for inverted normals when attribute tangents are not present. There should be nothing to compensate for when tangents are present because screen-space derivatives are not being used.  I also suggested we may be able to fix this automatically by honoring the flag in the shader. I did not say we would fix this automatically be flipping
column12: however. I do not think we should alter the user\'s settings.  In any event
column13: before we go down that path
column14: I think it is imperative that we verify this hypothesis:  >[Y]ou should be able to compensate by setting normalScale.y = 1 for any model that properly adheres to the glTF spec.  We must have an explanation for every model that is not being rendered correctly."'

column10: b'b"  Yes
column11: apologies
column12: I did not intend to be dictating that sort of implementation detail.  I\'m just trying to make sure there\'s not a misunderstanding of what _honoring the flag_ means mathematically
column13: for the purpose of screen-space tangent generation. That sounds like that could potentially be a large set.  If there are indeed models out there that are doing something radically different than the official test models
column14: and yet could still be considered valid uses of normal maps in glTF
column15: that would be important to discover.  The test models are intended to cover valid uses of normal maps on static (non-transformed) geometry.  There shouldn\'t be a way
column16: particularly when relying on viewer-generated tangent vectors
column17: to construct the model in some other coordinate system and yet claim that it\'s valid glTF."'

column10: b"b' GLTFLoader: Extensibility'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: We are currently implement [b3dm]url  (a format that encapsulates glTF) support in our project and have encountered a few problems with the current GLTFLoader implementation.  We need to support addition attribute (
column12: used to identify the different objects packed in the geometry)
column13: extensions ([CESIUM_RTC]url  and potentially additional uniforms. However
column14: there does not seem to be any way to add these new features without modifying the GLTFLoader file itself.  So my question is: how to support the extensible nature of glTF? Do we contribute directly to the source and add the  that we need? Or does the loader need to be modified so extensions can be "plugged in" without changing the source?  Related question: when loading glTFs in a scene rendered using a logarithmic depth buffer
column15: the model\\\'s shader are not modified to account for it
column16: resulting in depth issues: url  I implemented a [small hack]url  to fix the problem. Should this process be added to the loader natively? Or could Three provide a helper function to patch the materials?\''

column10: b'b"  Hi @Jeremy-Gaillard \\xe2\\x80\\x94 I like the idea of modifying the glTF loader to support user-defined extensions
column11: rather than just the extensions we\'ve implemented ourselves. This would make it much easier to support draft extensions like #11577. Definite +1 from me on that. Hopefully we could do this by having a common interface for all extensions with methods like
column13: ....  However
column14: I think we would be implementing that extensibility on GLTF2Loader
column15: and not GLTFLoader \\xe2\\x80\\x94 are you able to upgrade to the newer loader? This seems specific to glTF1
column16: as glTF2 does not have custom shaders currently. If it\'s not too much trouble
column17: it may be best to keep your hack as-is
column18: and if it\'s still an issue when GLTF2Loader gets custom shader support later
column19: we\'ll figure it out then. Most development work is on GLTF2Loader at this point.  Some background on the shader thing: custom GLSL shaders were part of the core glTF1.0 specification
column20: and the default export format in COLLADA2GLTF. Since glTF2.0
column21: they\'ve been moved to an optional extension
column22: and that extension hasn\'t been fully defined yet. The default now is metal-rough PBR
column23: with options for spec-gloss PBR or blinn-phong."'

column10: b'b" I now have a fully working version of that is able to load all OBJ file data into indexed BufferGeometry
column11: see #12048 and url It all boils down to this ([see code]url  When the faces instructions in OBJ are parsed
column12: a key is build from the vertex
column13: uv and normal index. When it does not exist the values are pushed to vertex
column14: uv and normal arrays respectively and the pointer is stored as a value and pushed to the indices array. If it exits the the value is retrieved and set to the indices array (=no extra storage). OBJLoader re-orders objects  by material and smoothing group. Therefore indices need to be [adjusted before]url  they stored in the final Arraybuffers. Multi-materials gave me a headache
column15: because the start and length need to reference the indices and not the vertices ([see code]url  This sounds super logic now
column16: but wasn\'t obvious because the meshes seemed to miss vertices
column17: but it was just due to wrong material group settings.  **See the following examples using indexed BufferGeometry:** [obj **Indexed**]url  [Bigger OBJ files stage (External) **Indexed**]url I added stats in the log of what was saved (=Multiple definitions). Stats from Female02 (first example). 72% less vertices: Stats from kitchen sink (second example). 78% less vertices. "'

column10: b'b\'  The thing is... OBJs have 3 different "index buffers". One for triangles
column11: one for normals and one for uvs. WebGL only supports 1 index buffer. So it\\\'s basically impossible to retain the original mapping when you\\\'re also trying to be performant and memory efficient.\''

column10: b'b" But
column11: you are able to store only unique face descriptions (at least per OBJ group in OBJLoader2 impl). This at least reduces the required  amount of memory without destroying information. Let\'s take the numbers from female02 above. The unindexed loader stores 18699*3*4 bytes vertices
column12: 18699*3*4 bytes normals and 18699*2*4 uvs bytes = 598.368 bytes.  The indexed version detected 5057 unique combination of  face definitions: 5057*3*4+5057*3*4+5057*2*4 bytes = 161.824 bytes and 18699*4 bytes index which results in 236.620 total bytes. You save 60 percent memory.  There are face descriptions without normals or uvs which I did not consider in the calculation above
column13: but this will not significantly change the result.  Ratios are better with quad based models. "'

If I understand the specs correctly understand the maximum index length is rather short and therefore not suited for large meshes: Another idea is to write a custom shader that access the different indices from a buffer texture in the vertex shader
column12: but this will decrease rendering performance ([see this stackoverflow post]url '"

column10: b"b' GLTFLoader: Flatter node hierarchy'"

b'b" The hierarchy that results from GLTF2Loader can be quite deep. There may be quite a few places where a node can be merged with its parent or even eliminiated. An obvious example is the creation of the node to represent the glTF entity
column11: as in e.g.  (glTF scene) (root node)   (mesh)   (primitive)  In many (most?) use cases
column12: exists only to hold an array of (and optionally one of associated morph target  ). The will always have the identity transform
column13: so has no influence on its descendants -but because it **can** have a unique name as well as optional and fields
column14: it is not a given that it can always be eliminated.  @donmccurdy outlined his own
column15: even deeper hierarchy resulting from a trivial 1-node model
column16: in url For the project I\'m working on
column17: our team must cope with complex scenes on mobile browsers
column18: with weak CPUs. Any gratutious transform multiplications that can be eliminated from render loops is very valuable to us. Then again
column19: it\'s not clear to which degree the user should be able to expect the glTF hierarchy to be mirrored in the resulting scene graph. It seems particularly unpleasant to perform node-collapsing optimization only in **some** cases (when no optional fields are present) in a loaded model
column20: so that the user has no way of knowing what topology to expect.  I had mentioned the possibility of an optimizing loader option
column21: where the user opts into a mode where they guarantee their structs will never have unique names
column22: extras or extensions
column23: and thus can always be eliminated / merged into its parent. But I don\'t know if that\'s the  way."'

column10: b'b\' Copied over from @stevenvergenz\\\'s comment in the glTF repo
column11: we should be able to reduce a single-node single-mesh glTF file to this:  * Scene (userland scene)   * Scene (glTF scene root)   * Mesh (glTF node)     * BufferGeometry (mesh)       * groups (primitives)     * Material[] (primitive materials)  I hadn\\\'t realized  existed
column12: so that should simplify things here.  The only open question IMO would be
column13: what to do with and on a "mesh" object
column14: since those aren\\\'t normally used on a :  (b) forcibly put and onto the BufferGeometry
column15: even if it\\\'s non-default in . (c) decide that  ignores and name on anything that isn\\\'t a node
column16: which is already true-ish because things like glTF buffers (which could have too) are not exposed in the GLTF2Loader output at all.  We could also start returning an array of and with the GLTF2Loader response
column17: but that\\\'s a slightly different issue for another time.\''

column10: b'b" Reopening this \\xe2\\x80\\x93 I\'m thinking we should actually be a bit _less_ aggressive about flattening while parsing the glTF model. We\'re pretty good today about flattening a node that only has one mesh

column12: but that\'s getting complex (e.g. to handle userData) and doesn\'t help us in cases where the node hierarchy in the original file is already silly
column13: like this recent case:  We should just naively output something as close as we can to the original file
column14: without merging nodes

column18: or in a utility method users can call) we have a flatten() method that operates on the result. For example:   @takahirox thoughts?"'

column10: b"b' Related: url '"
b'b\' One thing that could be also implemented is a set of "pre-passes" when adding a new Pass to the Composer the composer checks for pre-requirements (example
column11: DepthBuffer RGBA
column12: DepthBuffer
column13: G-Buffer XPTO
column14: etc)  The Effect composer renders all these pre-requirements and makes the results available to all passes

b'b\' personally i see more suitability in a 2 data-structure approach:  Pass Buffer  a pass would define input and output buffers. In "Postprocess" system simply provide some input buffers (or passes that without inputs) and declare what buffer you want to be rendered to screen. Whole thing with swapping is pretty fiddly.  A pass can declare more than 1 input A pass can declare more than 1 input  A buffer can be extended to a more generic thing called "variable" with additional types beyond FrameBuffer\''

b'b" @donmccurdy  I did some digging and think I gained some surface-level knowledge on this topic of color management.  I think  utilizes linear color space throughout it\'s pipeline for lighting calculations
column11: etc.  So when you flag the  as sRGB
column12: it removes the gamma correction so calculations can correctly be done in linear color space.  I think this is the right approach and is followed by most standard 3D applications.  However
column13: by default
column14: doesn\'t gamma correct it\'s rendering output by default.  So removing the gamma correction in sRGB texture results in a darker than intended output. @Maplesog Try adding the following to your renderer.    This should perform the proper gamma correction."'

b"b' Feature request: Increase raycaster collision detection performance through spatial search trees'"

b'b" I have built a VR application similar to [WebVR-Vive-Dragging]url  that allows to interact with numerous 3d objects using VR controllers. This means that a user can grab an object with a VR controller and can move or scale it. **Problem**: When there are complex 3d objects in the scene
column11: i.e. objects having geometries with a very large number of vertices
column12: then the raycasting during the collision detection gets very slow. Hence
column13: the problem is the complexity of the geometry of one object.  There are tree data structures for fast spatial search
column14: such as [Octree]url  or [R-Tree]url  I have found [threeocttree]url  that allows to split up a geometry into smaller chunks but it seems that it is a bit out of date ( r60).  As far as I see
column15: in object\'s method there are already some performance optimizations (checking bounding box and sphere first before doing actual raycast). Maybe it would make sense to have another such check stage using spatial search trees?! What do you think?  Kind regards"'

column10: b'b" At the risk of stating the obvious
column11: but have you tried the version of that\'s already in the repo([]url "'

column10: b'b" I don\'t vote for a hard-wired usage of spatial search trees in  . The  of such algorithms overbalances the performance gain in many applications. This is reasonable and should be sufficient. If users need more performance in context of more advanced use cases
column11: they can use the mentioned example as a starting point. Octrees might be a good choice. But i\'ve never seen a R-Tree solution in interactive 3D applications because its approach is quite sophisticated (the algorithm performs data instead of space partitioning)."'

column10: b'b\' Hello and thanks for your replies
column11: @Mugen87 I agree that many use cases do not require such fast searches. However
column12: having a mechanism for interacting with 3D objects (and I guess that is the case what it is mostly used for)
column13: \\\'s step from checking bounding  first (which I totally agree to be reasonable) in let\\\'s say constant time to a linear time effort when doing the actual raycast is quite big. I could imagine a kind of "per-geometry-search tree" instead of one global search tree. As long as the geometry does not change (oftentimes transformations are much more likely than geometry changes) the search tree does not need to be updated.  That\\\'s why I thought
column14: such kind of optimization using spatial search trees could be a more integral part of  . But I also understand that this causes additional complexity and overhead.  @moraxy I will have a look at the example version. I just wanted to know if such a feature would make sense.  Thanks again and kind regards \''

Since is  this search tree does not need to be changed after initializing it. This would reduce some overhead for . An Octree would be a good starting point ([similar concept in BabylonJS]url '"

b"b' I just implemented a better method for raycasting on PlaneBufferGeometry.  I use the far parameter and find the first and last index positions.  This works in planebuffer because the index array is in x/y order. Once outside the x/y bounding box all collision must be outside the far range.  Is there any desire to commit this somewhere?  Current implementation is specific to my use case but I would be willing to try and make more generic if desired. I was able to reduce my raycasting performace significantly on a large planeBuffer(2.5 seconds to 10ms)'"
b"b' @kpetrow I think the  octree examples are adequate. You are of course free to share your code on GitHub if you feel it would be useful to others.'"
b'b" I have suggested spatial index to be included into threejs in the past. There have been some work in this direction
column11: and existing oct-tree example is one of those. Ultimately
column12: i think it\'s lack of interest from the core community with respect to having this functionality as first-class citizen in three.  I would be happy to donate my BVH code to the project
column13: if there is sufficient interest and intent to include it into the main distribution (not examples). My code focuses on 2 aspects: dynamic scenes fast insert fast deletion refitting (ability for nodes to change shape without having to be re-inserted) query speed  I have 2 implementations: BinaryBVH very compact
column14: using ByteBuffer   mix of UintX and FloatX types via DataView great for serialization can be compressed using standard tools like lzma library immutable build speed is highly optimized only works for BufferGeometry SAH optimization ray queries BVH Object tree
column15: as a consequence is a lot larger than binary implementation mutable fast bulk insert fast single item insert refitting stack
column16: recursive and stack-less traversal implementations (different performance characteristics) SAH optimization Frustum queries Ray queries  Personally
column17: i can\'t live without a spatial index
column18: it is a difference between n^2 and log(n) performance. For example
column19: in my current project following parts rely on spatial index: foliage system (trees
column20: flowers
column21: bushes etc) all object placement (characters and houses) picking (used in interactions
column22: such as mouse clicks)  url terrain has about 1m polygons
column23: and placing thousands of trees and running real-time ray-casts on that is simply a no-go
column24: especially for lower-end devices."'

column10: b"b' I would like to see anything that makes raycast optimized.  Is there any room for optimization without adding complexity? Octree requires all new library
column11: with all new adds and updates
column12: etc..  One thing i notice is that once a geometry is converted to a indexed buffer array
column13: It no longer uses the properties of the original geometry smartly.  As mentioned above plane buffer geometries can be super optimized by knowing that the arrayBuffer came from a PlaneGeometry.  Maybe overwriting the  ( raycaster
column14: intersects ) method to be based on the geometry type?'"

column10: b"b' Another approach is to have Raycaster as a separate plug-in -as are the interactive controls and the loaders. Then
column11: adding a performant raycaster similar to what @Usnul proposes would be great.'"

column10: b"b' I like the idea of having pluggable Raycasters
column11: but I think there is a bit of confusion. What I think to be useful is a spatial index
column12: not a Raycaster per-se. Spatial index allows things like: spatial culling (think frustum culling) doing visibility queries building a path tracing renderer fast sorting (exploiting data locality)  currently  does 2 of these explicitly (sorting and culling) and 1 via examples (Ray-tracing renderer)  maintaining a spatial index internally would accelerate sorting and culling
column13: giving progressively more benefit for larger scenes at the cost of extra RAM required to store the index.'"

column10: b'b" Why don\'t you just use GPU picking? There are some examples around and it is fairly easy to implement. The performance is night and day. In our use cases
column11: with models of over a million polygons
column12: the picking went from nearly a second to running in realtime at 60fps while dragging things over the model.  url "'

column10: b'b\' @hccampos  GPU picking is not necessarily faster than doing it on CPU
column11: for GPU you have to render at resolution proportional to precision you desire
column12: so if you want pixel accuracy you have to render at 1:1 screen resolution. Bear in mind that this is a separate render pass
column13: you\\\'re rendering objects as separate distinct colors. An extra render pass means graphics memory usage (typical for deferred pipeline).  Using a binary space partitioning index gives you log(n) timing profile on your picking
column14: so for 1
column16: 000 polygons you\\\'d be looking at about 14 operations to resolve a ray query. Depending on your data structure it\\\'s likely to take a few microseconds
column17: allowing you thousands of queries before you start making a dent in your frame budget.  Lets make a comparison
column18: lets say you have a 1m poly model
column19: and you wish to cast a ray from screen space directly along camera direction into the scene (picking use-case). Lets assume you are going with the bottom of the barrel resolution
column20: full hd
column21: or 1920 \\xc3\\x97 1080. Lets assume you render RGB only (24 bit per pixel)
column22: you will need 6220800byte (about 6 Mb) or graphics RAM to render that. If you use CPU solution
column23: lets say you go with AABB BVH with 10 polygons per leaf
column24: that mean you need about 200
column25: 000 nodes
column26: lets say each node is about 6 * 8bytes for coordinates
column27: intermediate nodes have extra 2 * 4 bytes for child pointers and leaf nodes have 10 * 4 bytes for polygon pointer
column28: that\\\'s 14
column30: 000 bytes (about 14Mb). Main difference comes into play when you conder the fact that your BVH queries have very little demand on RAM bandwidth
column32: and there\\\'s only a handful of operations involved per query
column33: compared to rendering full 1m poly geometry.  If you take a resolution that\\\'s more typical for desktops
column35: you end up with 11059200byte render target (11Mb).  If you have a large budget of graphics ram bandwidth and a fairly decent shader core count sure
column36: that\\\'s a simple and straight-forward way of doing picking.\''

column10: b"b' @Usnul absolutely
column11: but it is probably the simplest solution to implement. Implementing and maintaining spatial index data structures will probably be a non-insignificant burden for the threejs maintainers.  That being said
column12: I would absolutely love to have a good
column13: well-tested and maintained spatial index data structure as part of three or as a separate npm package.'"

column10: b'b" I was curious about implementing such a spatial index for my used geometries so I implemented a quite simple Octree (create and search only) that splits up my BufferGeomtry. With this simple solution I achieved quite promising results: applied on a geometry with about 500K vertices the raycast time reduced from ~120ms to ~2.3ms. Construction of the tree currently takes ~500ms but since geometry and tree creation is done inside a web worker only once on application start
column11: this is not a such a problem.  I guess the algorithm could be quite easily integrated into and maybe switched on or off using a flag such as  \'s  . This way
column12: it could be used only when BufferGeometry is not supposed to change. Unfortunately
column13: I had to overwrite  \'s method though I only needed to change two lines in it (Octree search call and position array iteration).  Anyway
column14: in my VR application I have to detect object-controller collisions during render loop and not only once on mouse click. Thus
column15: I have to rely on my current solution. I will try if I can further improve it. **UPDATE** I made a mistake in measuring the raycast time. The correct value is ~2.3ms (instead of ~0.3ms). I changed the value above accordingly. "'
