column11: as well (though I have since found other solutions for our raycast needs)
column12: but I figured I\'d contribute some of my experiments
column13: too. It\'s a bit rough
column14: but I put this together a few months ago: url It adds a function to the THREE geometry objects and overrides the raycast function to use that (and only returns the first hit as an added optimization). It\'s only really beneficial for static
column15: highly complex meshes and doesn\'t do anything to spatially segment the scene. Here\'s the [demo]url  where you can see the difference in raycast performance on an 80
column16: 000 triangle mesh. Computing the bounds tree is a little slow
column17: but with a little work it could probably be smoother.  Regarding my opinion on this
column18: I feel a bit conflicted. This feels like something that can be built pretty well as an extension to THREE. And ultimately it doesn\'t seem like doing per-triangle checks / collisions / casts for complex or animated meshes is optimal
column19: anyway. In simple cases it might be fine
column20: but it seems like using the typical plane / cube / sphere / capsule representations or simplified meshes would be better suited for enabling super-fast raycasting (or occlusion-culling
column21: collisions
column22: etc) in complex cases. Of course
column23: if you\'re looking for pixel-perfect casts this doesn\'t work quite as well
column24: but the right solution really depends on your use case.  @Usnul @matthias-w Are either of your octree / BVH implementations open source or available online? I\'d definitely be interested in taking a look!"'

column10: b'b" @gkjohnson  >Are either of your octree / BVH implementations open source or available online? I\'d definitely be interested in taking a look!  The code is not open source currently. I could provide you the sources if you contact me privately.  There\'s an example I did for instanced meshes: url  The above example includes following: BVH is updated dynamically as new instances are inserted into the tree BVH is optimized incrementally using depth 1-2 rotations on the fly BVH is sampled with a frustum query to which instances to render  I have a version of it running in the game i\'m working on: url  With respect to your implementation. I like it
column11: mine is different in 2 major ways: I focus on performance I focus on memory footprint I avoid garbage collection in many places  Some more specific points: I also use a mixture of splitting strategies transparently
column12: based on what you want to do with the BVH My BVH is AABB based I support updates to node bounds via refitting "'

b'b" Sorry for the late response. @gkjohnson The code is not open source. Additionally
column11: your solution sounds much more sophisticated than mine. Thus
column12: I guess there is not so much to learn from my solution.  @sid3007 I am not sure if I understand your problem. I can explain my approach. Maybe it is helpful.  My use case is quite simple. When my application starts
column13: the geometries for different models are loaded. These models can be transformed by the user. The geometries do not change. There are no geometry deformations. Hence
column14: I implemented a very simple Octree that is built once for every geometry when the application starts. The octree is not dynamic. It is built based on the bounding box of the given geometry and the array of vertices. During its construction it checks whether an octant contains a vertex or the octant\'s  Box3  bounding box intersects with a triangle (three consecutive vertices in non-indexed geometry) and stores the vertex array references with the octree\'s node. The per-mesh octree is then stored along with the mesh. I also overwrite my mesh instances\' \'s  raycast  method (just one line) in order to actually call the octree intersection test method. This returns the geometries face vertex indices that can be used by the mesh\'s default intersection logic. I did one optimization: the octree creation is done once on app start inside a WebWorker (actually a pool of workers). The reason is that the tree creation for large geometries takes quite some time (some seconds). This would block the browser UI so I moved it to another thread. I hope my approach becomes clear.  "'

column10: b'b" @EliasHasle  If you\'re interested in raycasting against static geometry I and others have put significant effort into [three-mesh-bvh]url  which uses a BVH to index triangles and allows high-performance raycasting as well as intersection detection against static complex geometry. The tree building process is more complex so it takes a bit longer but takes raycasting down to under a millisecond and often under 0.1ms when raycasting against geometry with hundreds of thousands of triangles.  The build time could be improved in a few different ways but it\'s been good enough for what I wanted to do with it -improving that is on the list
column11: though.  I would like to build a dynamic scene-based octree to enable better raycasting and collision detection for scenes with lots of meshes but I haven\'t had a good use case myself. Maybe some day!"'

column10: b'b" @EliasHasle My implementation is a tree of JS class objects (I use ES6 classes
column11: i.e. prototype instances). Basically
column12: a node is a tree in my implementation. However
column13: I have an additional Octree class that holds the root node and provides methods for building and searching (and also some debugging and visualization) the tree.  I did not experiment much with the values for maximum tree node level and maximum number of vertices per leaf node. Maybe there is a better combination.  I also use a bounding volume hierarchy to accelerate intersection tests. So I test the mesh\'s bounding sphere and bounding box before actually checking on the mesh geometry\'s octree. I can recommend a book that is a very nice collection of collision detection approaches: C. Ericson
column14: Real-Time Collision Detection
column15: CRC Press
column16: 2004  @gkjohnson That looks great! The performance is impressive. What kind of BVH are you using?"'

column10: b'b" @matthias-w Thanks!  There are a couple split strategy options but splitting the BVH nodes on the center of the longest side builds the tree the fastest. The triangles are partitioned into sides based on the center of their bounds and the tree nodes are expanded to fully contain the child triangles (so there\'s a small amount of overlap of tree nodes)."'
b'b\' @gkjohnson So then the BVH implementation is a kind of unbalanced Kd-tree with axis selection dependent on box shape
column11: right? If so
column12: I was thinking about doing something like that for cases where the root BB was too far from a cube
column13: and then using octrees after the conditional splitting. This would presumably apply well to cases such as @Usnul\\\'s map world
column14: where initial splitting would be in the two "map" dimensions and subsequent splitting would proceed in 3D. I think it is a much better solution than mine
column15: which is to expand the root BB to a bounding cube with the same center
column16: and then use octree splitting all the way.\''

column10: b'b" Oh dear
column11: i think i\'ve found the issue :unamused:  The problem is the setup of light uniforms in  :  url The setup of lights is done once per frame. But when a reflector is rendered
column12: it overwrites the lights setup because it executes a rendering of the scene in  . The problem is now that this setup is not reverted. So depending on the order of the reflector in the render list
column13: subsequent objects are rendered with the wrong light setup. Or to be more precise
column14: with the wrong view matrix (the one of the reflector\'s virtual camera).  I think we have to find a way to restore the light setup after possible changes in  ."'

column10: b"b' One possible workaround: Set the of a reflector to a high value.  url But we definitely need a conceptual solution for this bug.'"

column10: b'b" This is related to my earlier thread url  which I have closed to continue here.  It is possible to use a resolution other than the \'standard\' resolution if set up before or on VRDisplayPresentChange; for one way see my code modification to  in that thread. Basically
column11: mrdoob\'s (). I would still like to see this in .  It is not possible to change it while presenting.  It used to be possible to change resolution dynamically by (1) stopping presentation
column12: (2) change resolution
column13: (3) re-request presentation
column14: but this no longer works in Chrome on Windows.  (not sure if that is a SteamVR change or a Chrome change)  Also note that SteamVR now gives a much higher suggested resolution for Vive
column15: probably to match the Vive Pro but also applying to the old Vive.  It is probably that change that dustinkerstein saw on Firefox.  BUT SteamVR does now offer a per application way to modify resolution."'

column12: and also more consistent with WebXR 1.1 where this would correspond with multiplying the  for getting the canvas size.  Side note

column14: that\'s 3.5 on my phone and accidentally plugging that in as a framebufferScaleMultiplier would be unhelpful."'

Other videos are working.  ![bildschirmfoto vom 2018-03-23 11-10-49]url []url #####  version  [x] r91 [x] r89  ##### Browser  [ ] All of them [x] Chrome [ ] Firefox [ ] Internet Explorer  ##### OS  [x] Linux '"

column10: b'b" Um
column11: it\'s not clear to me what\'s your issue. Can you please provide a live example that demonstrates the problem?"'

column10: b'b" I can try to do thet
column11: but I\'m not shoure when I will have the time for that. The probelm is
column12: that I use the loaded video data to create the geometry of the mesh on the left side. That part is working fine. But when I load the video on to the plain
column13: the video has not the right rotation like in the video element on the right side.  I will try to create an example in the next days."'

column10: b"b' Please try your video with this [live demo]url  ) and test if the orientation is correct.'"
b"b' I checked it and the rotation is wrong. I also noticed
column11: that Windows Media-Player is also not rotating the file correctly. In VLC-Player is the rotation right.  ![test]url  url '"

column10: b'b" I don\'t think that\'s a related issue. Or do you have a suggestion what the library should make different?"'
b"b' I would expect that the texture has the same rotation like the video element I putted in. Or do you know a way to detract the rotation?'"
b'b"  No. And i don\'t think that\'s the task of a 3D library. You should first investigate why Windows Media-Player shows the same behavior."'

b'b" The reason for this is most likely the video rotation metadata that has been saved in the video when filming on a mobile device. The mobile will record the video with whatever its default rotation is
column11: then add in the rotation metadata for video players to use when playing back. The reason I believe is to reduce any video processing needed during recording.  Modern browsers will use this to rotate the videos in playback when using  tags
column12: however not when rendering to the canvas as ThreeJS does. This rotation metadata is not available to Javascript
column13: so can\'t be used by ThreeJS to rotate the video.  I think the solution is to transcode the video without the rotation metadata."'

column10: b"b' Thanks for the replies
column11: then I have to close this issue and try to convert the files on the server.'"

column10: b"b' @calrk Thanks for your explanation!'"
b"b' @kenrussell what do you think about this? the browser applies the rotation specified in the video metadata when displaying it with but the rotation gets lost when using it as a texture.'"
b"b' I will reopen this and maybe you could make a feature out of this.'"
b'b"  That\'s the reason why can\'t do anything here. So reopening this issue makes no sense to me."'
b'b" Yes I agree with @Mugen87 . Given my research into the problem I don\'t believe the solution can be implemented in without updates to the browser video spec."'
b"b' Maybe the video texture could load the video as file resource and read the file rotation direct?'"
b"b' I think the browser is going to handle this (at least chrome).'"

b"b' Instanced Geometry Suggestion'"
b'b" I successfully created a ground foliage system using instanced buffer geometry. Setting up the instancing wasn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t nearly as bad as I though it would be
column11: however one aspect was just downright tedious.  What I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m referring to is recreating the Lambert shader manually and then adding in the custom orientation / position adjustments. This was necessary for the foliage material to respect scene lighting / shadows etc. Rebuilding the Lambert Material into a ShaderMaterial was not fun.  Would it not be easier to have a few for example: ShaderChunks[\\xe2\\x80\\x98Instancing\\xe2\\x80\\x99]? If I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m not overlooking anything
column12: it would just require a few chunks
column13: an instancing_pars chunk which could contain the instancing attributes and applyQuaternionToVector function (from  dev instancing examples)
column14: and one right after the \\xe2\\x80\\x98begin_vertex\\xe2\\x80\\x99 chunk to alter the vec3 transformed variable using the function.  Would this not be much more user friendly? If a user wants to take advantage of instancing (who wouldn\'t)
column15: they simply have to set instancing: true on the material and of course set up the needed buffer attributes. They would no longer have to manually reconstruct an entire materials shader.  I\'ve seen more complex examples of trying to ease usage of instancing
column16: perhaps we should start with something a little more simple like this?  I\\xe2\\x80\\x99d be more than happy to make a PR
column17: if this is desirable."'

column10: b'b" I also took a stab at this. I wanted to have instancing for Foliage
column11: and I wanted to be able to edit the instances in: count instanced attribute values  I also wanted to be able to reference each instance individually
column12: so I can remove it later or edit its attributes (position
column13: rotation
column14: scale).  I ended up writing a lot of code
column15: mostly due to abstractions which are required to achieve this
column16: the end result was being able to render millions of instances while being able to manipulate them at runtime. Some problems I ended up solving:  material rewriting (based on @pailhead\'s approach
column17: that was very helpful) have to also create a .customDepthMaterial to get shadows to work instance index  reference mapping dynamic resizing of number of instances
column18: including standard things like over-allocation to reduce chance of rebuilding the attributes entirely. make random removes cheap on average ( O(1) ) (e.g. index 1234 out of 5000 instances) spatial index abstraction on top of that
column19: to only include instances that are visible
column20: this removes a limit of number of instances to some degree binary . Reducing time and size footprint of the instance set."'

column10: b'b\' @titansoftime  There are some tricks you can do. Simplest one is to not rebuild BufferGeometry and let it have more attributes than what you\\\'re actually using
column11: at some later point you may decide that it\\\'s too big and it\\\'s not worth it to keep using all that memory and rebuild it
column12: but that\\\'s an arbitrary point in time of your choosing. I use an already existing BVH implementation and populate it with references to individual instance (references are just int32 values). BVH leaves have an actual bounding box (AABB) for the instance. Here\\\'s what a leaf looks like:  My culling code looks like this:   Code for the  :  I have a compact binary table for keeping instance transforms beside BVH
column13: that way BVH remains fairly small and is traversed quite quickly.  You probably noticed
column14: but this means that I have to essentially compute a bounding box for every instance. This is actually not that big a deal
column15: I compute one for each instance specifically
column16: but you could use an overestimated one by taking the bounding sphere and scaling that
column17: for my usecase I\\\'m okay paying extra for creation of an instance for the benefit of having a really tight box at runtime. That\\\'s also a reason why I don\\\'t rebuild the entire thing every time but use efficient serialization format to just load thousands of already processed instances.  Also
column18: regarding culling i just turn it off on the  with respect to performance. I made a small toy example with 1
column20: 000 boxes. Scene volume: 2000x2000x2000 camera near plane: 0.01 camera far plane: 100  moving camera around takes under 1ms on my hardware to run that  . Here\\\'s a sample "bad" frame: ![image]url  entire frame took 1.4ms here

column10: b"b' Actually i stand corrected for the normals being needed. For OBJ in particular
column11: i think exporting the normals
column12: basically considers smoothing groups inside of 3ds max. Meaning
column13: a hard edge that is generated by smoothing groups (shared vertices) in 3ds max
column14: gets translated to a split (douple vertices) in . Normals are needed to indicate this split (hard edge) i think. But
column15: the source object could also be modified
column16: to include an actual split at hard edges (double vertices). '"

column10: b'b" Vertex normals are required for a tangent-space normal map. For proper rendering
column11: they must be the same as the normals assumed when the normal map was created. is a heuristic that computes \'reasonable\' normals. I would not rely on the client using that method if a tangent-space map is being used.  >What do you suggest be done if anything with this?  Nothing
column12: really. It is well-known that modeling tools and rendering engines have differing approaches to dealing with normal maps."'

column10: b'b\' >Vertex normals are required for a tangent-space normal map. For proper rendering
column11: they must be the same as the normals assumed when the normal map was created.  They do not depend on normals alone
column12: but I believe OBJ can\\\'t even store these. I think one might use a heuristic since the results are going to be subjectively incorrect (without the tangent frame
column13: it\\\'s impossible to tell what "correct" is). Proper rendering thus may become arbitrary.\''

b"b' KeyframeTrack: Option to disable ?'"
b'b" By default
column11: the KeyframeTrack constructor calls and  . Those calls are unnecessary for animations that are already optimized
column12: and problematic if the track is going to be split later
column13: such as in url  From the *Oat the Goat* [technical writeup]url  \\xe2\\x80\\x94  An option in the KeyframeTrack constructor doesn\'t really help
column14: because they\'re typically not created directly
column15: and the option would need to be passed through all of the loaders. We could disable the optimization and let users trigger it manually
column16: but I do think it\'s a reasonable default. What about a (global) opt-out flag? "'

column10: b'b" Hm
column11: not only does KeyframeTrack call on itself when created
column12: but AnimationClip calls on each track again when they\'re passed into its constructor? That does seem redundant... \\xf0\\x9f\\xa4\\x94"'

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: optimization and validation in exporters rather than in  sounds more reasonable. I haven\'t looked into the code yet (I\'m in the airport now!) but I\'m wondering how the CPU time for will be if we remove redundancy."'

column10: b'b" Unless there is a valid reason to call more than once on the same instance
column11: wouldn\'t it be better to just set an  -flag once an instance is optimized? On consecutive calls to
column12: it just sees if the flag is set and aborts immediately. That way we won\'t have breaking changes in the API
column13: while still removing the redundancy. "'

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m a bit weary of "optimize"
column11: I think  should take care of that
column12: alternatively it should be in the user domain. Validation only makes sense in the asset pipeline
column13: I think
column14: let\\\'s say deserialization code is justified to perform validation
column15: but that\\\'s about it.\''

column10: b'b"  The problem is there are two redundancies: we call twice
column11: but even one call would be pointless if the author has already optimized their animation
column12: which we have no way of knowing (and most likely
column13: they have not). I\'m not suggesting any breaking API changes
column14: just a way for an author to indicate their animation does not need to be optimized without forking KeyframeTrack. It would be ideal for optimization to happen before animation is brought into
column15: but that\'s a much harder problem. In any case we should keep the method around
column16: because using it and then storing the result with is a completely valid way of creating an optimization step."'

column10: b'b\' @RemusMar  & @donmccurdy Do you expect them to be re-exported in the "optimized" way? Asset pipeline is something everyone has
column11: some put more effort into it that others
column12: some pipelines are completely custom while others are heavily standardized etc. I am not advocating for removal of validation and optimization methods I think they are wonderful tools that serve real need. I believe that it\\\'s reasonable to assume that once an animation is loaded it is: * valid * expressed as desired (no optimization is wanted)  When these assumptions are insufficient
column13: i believe it is reasonable to offer the tools (  and  ) to the user in order to deal with such usecases.  ### Unrelated: @donmccurdy writeup on GOat was quite insightful
column14: especially part about glTF exporter. They said they wrote 13k lines for that interactive experience which
column15: when reading the writeup
column16: indicated me think that there\\\'s a lot of room for improvement in glTF export as well as animation module and  in general. @RemusMar  "Everything in moderation". I don\\\'t subscribe to your view
column17: backwards compatibility is critical for some applications and harmful for others. Language design is one example where backwards compatibility is a clear net negative for the user
column18: take C++ as example
column19: there are a fraction of a percent of a percent of C++ developers who can rightfully claim to know all of \\\'standard\\\' C++ thanks to backwards compatibility. Backwards compatibility is expensive
column20: it bloats your code
column21: it takes time
column22: it leads to rigidity in your architecture which strongly opposes evolution and progress.  is not backwards compatible
column23: I enjoy migration and deprecation notices
column24: but that\\\'s not backwards compatibility
column25: I can\\\'t boot up my application written against  r50 in  r93 and expect it to work it doesn\\\'t. There is something called "semantic versioning" which might be a good thing for people to familiarize themselves with
column26: if not to practice religiously. /rant\''

b'b" Let\'s start with one of three things:  1. Provide a global opt-out. 2. Provide a per-instance opt-out and allow passing that setting into every  loader 3. Not call .optimize() and .validate() by default
column11: let users call them manually.  I would prefer (1).  @RemusMar given that we currently call by default
column12: do you consider (3) to be backward-incompatible? I think that is the only option on the table that potentially breaks back-compat. Sure. Keep in mind that they evaluated FBX
column13: JSON
column14: and DAE and had even less success with those. But glTF is a new format and we\'re fully aware great support from exporters is going to take time
column15: and that\'s a high priority for Khronos Group. The most effective way to improve things
column16: other than PRs
column17: is to give specific feedback in the appropriate repositories. I\'m also working on other points mentioned in the article
column18: not just this one."'

column12: so if someone could explain it I would appreciate it; the way I see it behaviour is still the same. Sure
column13: it might be running a bit or a lot slower
column14: but functionally it\\\'s the same.  @haroldiedema  that\\\'s a good example
column15: and my answer would be just run explicitly on any imported assets.  My objection stems from my experience with compilers
column16: there\\\'s a strong need for correct functionality
column17: but performance is typically an optional requirement
column18: at least it has a gradient. You produce functionally correct code
column19: and then you either optimize it as needed (online optimizations such as hot-spot) or you have special flags in static compilers
column20: and even projects like url  which go above and beyond "reasonable" optimizations. This kind of approach puts trade-off between startup time and runtime performance into the hands of users instead of saying "we know what\\\'s best for you
column21: you\\\'re going to have it this way
column22: and you\\\'re going to enjoy it" which
column23: by the way
column24: is also a totally valid strategy.\''

b'b\' The glTF format supports PBR and unlit shaders at this time. Whether the BabylonJS and FBX2GLTF tools do the Phong-to-PBR conversion in a way that preserves Phong specular maps
column11: I don\\\'t know \\xe2\\x80\\x94 that would be a question for the repos of those tools. If you are trying to preserve the exact appearance of models using classic Phong shaders
column12: you may have an easier time with other formats. This is a deliberate decision and not a bug. Base color and emissive textures in glTF (and
column13: typically
column14: diffuse textures in any format...) are in sRGB colorspace. GLTFLoader marks them as such ( )
column15: so that they\\\'re converted to linear colorspace for correct PBR lighting calculations. Finally colors should be converted back to sRGB (e.g.  ).  If you skip all of this
column16: with any format
column17: lighting calculations are incorrect. SEA3DLoader
column18: FBXLoader
column19: and ColladaLoader never touch the property of any texture
column20: and leave it to the end user to change texture colorspace and renderer colorspace. I\\\'m pretty confident that the large majority of  users are passing sRGB colors into  without converting
column21: despite the fact that renderer lighting calculations assume linear colorspace
column22: and getting results that are "good enough" but inconsistent with other engines and authoring environments. For correct results you should be using
column23: and marking sRGB textures as sRGB.  None of these issue are specific to glTF (see url  but with GLTFLoader we\\\'re trying to achieve consistency with other engines and 3D authoring environments
column24: and have chosen to treat all sRGB textures as sRGB for a first step. If you\\\'re mixing models from other formats in the scene
column25: then yes it\\\'s awkward
column26: and you\\\'d need to either mark the diffuse textures of those formats as sRGB or mark the colorspace on the glTF models to linear (the latter is incorrect for all model formats involved
column27: but may look good enough if you don\\\'t need precise colors).  ***  It does not seem like there is anything actionable here
column28: unless there are specific issues we can report to the tools mentioned. @RemusMar if you are happy with your SEA3D workflow
column29: that\\\'s great \\xe2\\x80\\x94 I\\\'m not interested in debating formats or persuading you to change from something that is already working well for you.\''

column10: b"b'  I think the Unity doc is precise in this point: _Returns the angle in degrees between two rotations a and b. Example: Think of two GameObjects (A and B) moving around a third GameObject (C). Lines from C to A and C to B create a triangle which can change over time. column10: b"b' Bounding boxes exist only on the CPU
column11: and that is where the frustum culling is occurring. Skinning occurs on the GPU.  So in your case
column12: either the skinned vertices are translated away from the bounding box
column13: or the bounding box is not correct for some reason. See if you can track that down.'"

column10: b"b' I see. Thanks!'"
b'b\' Yea
column11: it seems like the skinned vertices are translated away from the bounding box:  ![capture]url So I guess there\\\'s no "easy" solution for this
column12: but to recalculate the position of the bounding box manually
column13: or set
column14: right? I mean
column15: I\\\'m not sure if it\\\'s worth the processing time of recalculating the bounding box
column16: when the model is animated
column17: for example.. Or..?\''

column10: b'b" You can enlarge the head\'s bound box

b"b' LOD: Consider adding hysteresis option.'"
b"b' With the LOD systems in Unreal
column11: Unity
column12: and Blender
column13: LODs have a threshold that offsets the distance where the LOD appears from the distance where it disappears
column14: to reduce flickering from small movements (e.g. head movement with roomscale VR). From [Unreal docs]url '"

column10: b"b' Hmm... Is there a video or more documentation that shows the flickering?'"
b"b' sounds like you would have to move sideways exactly at the right distance. how likely is that?'"

b'b\' I can make a screencapture but it would be a bit subjective \\xe2\\x80\\x94 whether it\\\'s actually noticeable depends mostly on the similarity of the two LOD levels and the transition distance. Not sideways
column11: but the point of this feature is that there should be no place on a game map where the user can step forward-back-forward and see an LOD change _twice_. So "hysteresis" reduces the total number of changes likely to be observed in practice.  ~~But this isn\\\'t terribly important to me currently
column12: and it\\\'s easy to implement in userland. I\\\'ll close this for now and let others comment here if they have a use for it.~~ :)\''

column10: b'b" Oh
column11: so it\'s like a range where the state is kept with the previous change?"'

column10: b'b" Right
column11: so if you\'re moving toward a tree and increase quality from LOD3 to LOD2 at 50m distance
column12: you\'d have to move back to 55m distance in order to drop back to LOD3."'

column10: b"b' could be done (along with multitude of other things) easily if LOD accepted user function returning level index instead of distances'"
b'b" True
column11: although if you strip out the selection of level index from []url  there isn\'t much code left for a user to implement anyway. ;) Similar properties exist in Unreal
column12: Unity
column13: and Blender
column14: although semantics differ \\xe2\\x80\\x94 distance vs screen coverage
column15: hysteresis as percentage of distance vs absolute value. I think a property is preferable to a callback function here
column16: because it can be (de)serialized."'

column10: b'b" Your file specifies no normals
column11: correct? Therefore the loader can\'t import them.  However

column14: and the computed normals are \'flat\' ones orthogonal to each face.  You are correct that the loader does not honor when computing normals."'

column10: b"b' ##### Description of the problem  The FBXLoader does not work with many skeleton animations. e.g.
column11: from . One example from Mixamo that fails is the following:   Character: WHITECLOWN N HALLIN  Animation: SAMBA DANCING  You can get this model by downloading it from Mixamo directly but I have also attached it to this issue. []url Here is the displayed result using the webgl_loader_ sample in THREE v96 modified to load the :  ![whiteclownsambadancing_fbxloader]url  _Screen shot using webgl_loader__ Here is the same FBX file displayed in AutoDesk FBX Review: ![whiteclownsambadancing_fbxreview]url  _Screen shot using AutoDesk FBX Review_  There are many other Mixamo  pairings that work fine with the FBXLoader but many that do not. It is possible (though not confirmed) that the ones that fail were created with Maya (this has been stated as a possible problem in some other issues).  Also
column12: the  file loads correctly in many other software including the Mixamo site itself and [url  The later is fully open source so you can see the exact code they use to perform the  transforms and animations. They actually use AssImp for their conversion and you can see the exact code there. In particular
column13: see the following for their FBX import 3D transform handling:  [url After digging into the FBXLoader code a bit
column14: it seems there may be several areas where the issue could lie:  There does not seem to be any code to honor the FBX inherit type on the nodes. There does not seem to be any code to implement  pivot points on the nodes (NOT the geometry transforms which are implemented).  The following code from the AutoDesk FBX SDK may be of some help for implementing both of the above
column15: esp. the code and comments in CalculateGlobalTransform():  [AutoDesk FBX source code ]url There are some other  issues which have not been fully addressed regarding incorrect FBX animations loaded via the FBXLoader (#11895
column17: #13821). This issue is about improving the FBXLoader
column18: not a particular file or asset pipeline. Please do not suggest use of FBX2GLTF (which just bakes the animations) or other converters.  Also
column19: we are willing to provide some help with design and coding
column20: if need be
column21: but doing a full solution with a PR is beyond our bandwidth at this time (ping @looeee @Kyle-Larson @takahirox ?).  #####  version  [ ] Dev [X] r96 [ ] ...  ##### Browser  [x] All of them [ ] Chrome [ ] Firefox [ ] Internet Explorer  ##### OS  [x] All of them [ ] Windows [ ] macOS [ ] Linux [ ] Android [ ] iOS  ##### Hardware Requirements (graphics card

column10: b'b" Thanks for the detailed bug report. This seems to be the same issue as #14864.  Can you explain what you mean by the above line?  doesn\'t support transformed pivot points
column11: so there is no way to do this directly. The only solution that I am aware of would be to create a parent for each model and apply the pivot transforms using that. However this is obviously not desirable
column12: since it involves creating extra nodes in the scene graph
column13: and would also probably add a lot of complexity to the animation section of the loader. Ideally we\'ll be able to solve this issue without resorting to this approach. The data on FBX transforms are taken from [this page]url  It\'s not completely clear from that
column14: but I\'ve found that FBX files can contain either the __FBX and Maya__ transform type detailed there _or_ the __3ds Max__ type. It seems likely that this issue stems from incomplete / incorrect application of the __FBX and Maya__ transform type. "'

column10: b'b\' Thanx for the fast reply. The "inherit type" issue I discussed is a property on the FBX node -see:  [url (The above link is to the 2014 FBX spec but I think it\\\'s the same on the 2017). This property
column11: essentially
column12: determines the equation to use for a node\\\'s complete
column13: global 3D transformation. There are 3 values for this:  eInheritRrSs (0) eInheritRSrs (1) eInheritRrs (2)  I think if the letter is cap
column14: then that transform is global (e.g.
column15:
R" = Also the code in the AssImp FBXConverter::GenerateTransformationNodeChain method [here]url  does something similar though they do not seem to use the InheritType property. It seems they are just doing tests for non-zero values of some properties (pivot vectors, etc.). One of the more interesting aspects of the AssImp code id that they have the same problem as we do with THREE -they must insert extra nodes in the hierarchy to accomplish the full 3D transform. Recall that the AssImp code is used Open3Mod and that correctly loads the offending Mixamo file.  I am not sure we can implement this in the current state of THREE without inserting additional nodes at the points where a pivot exists (though we might be able to). Of course, if THREE added pivot points (rotation and scale) to their 3D transform matrix calculations, this would be a lot easier.  Your hunch on Maya vs. 3DS Max may in fact be right. Maybe the Mixamo characters created in 3DS Max work in FBXLoader and those created in Maya do not. If I get some time, I can dump some more data in FBXLoader to determine the authoring application of the bad vs. good Mixamo FBX files.  \''
threejs	14903	open	3	looeee	2018-09-12 13:11:24	205.05			+1	b'b\' Thanks for the info. I\\\'ve looked over the links you provided, especially [AutoDesk FBX source code ]url  which I hadn\\\'t seen before. I think I was incorrect about the meaning of _pivot_ in the context of FBX transforms. It seems like pivot actually means "global transform matrix" here so it\\\'s possible to apply all the pivot transforms via matrix transforms. The exception is the 3DS Max style data, referred to as the _3DS Max object-offset concept_ in the FBX docs. I had been implementing this by transforming the geometry of each mesh, thinking it was a hack to get around the lack of pivot points, but actually it seems like that may be the correct interpretation after all. I\\\'ll have a go at implementing the transform code from that link. It will be sometime next week before I have time to do it, however. \''
threejs	14903	open	4	radman-rt	2018-09-12 13:11:24	1246.63			+1	b"b' OK, that sounds great.  BTW, one thing I found handy is the AutoDesk FBX Converter -2013 is the latest version I found  [here]url  It is very nice since you can convert to ASCII and view the data much easier. I will continue some further research to find the differences between the working and failing FBX files. Let me know if I can provide any further info or assistance. '

column10: b'b\' After #14933
column11: model (
column13: etc ) transforms are applied correctly according to the FBX spec.  However
column14: it seems like there are still issues with how transforms are applied to bones and / or animation nodes. I\\\'m going to link some reference info here that may help me or someone else figure out what the problem is:  Bones (cluster nodes in FBX) have [three additional matrices]url  and a "mode" associated with them:  * the initial global transform of the mesh that the bone is controlling. These should be safe to ignore
column15: apparently they are largely legacy and will be the same for every bone in the case of a single skinned mesh.  * the bone\\\'s global transform at the moment of binding.  *  this also appears to be ignored in FBX SDK example code
column16: and is only needed dependant on the value of according to docs. * [ELinkMode]url  this specifies whether vertex weights need to be normalized
column17: and is currently ignored. There is some information in the following links regarding how to apply transformations to bone nodes:  * [Useful things you might want to know about FBXSDK]url  * [Calculating bind pose matrix and animation bone transforms]url  * [Getting the local transformation matrix for the vertices of a cluster?]url It\\\'s mentioned in a couple of places that the correct matrix for the bone at the time of binding is  Which I am interpreting to mean:   However
column18: so far
column19: attempting to do this in the loader has not given good results.  \''

column10: b"b' Replace bi-directional syncing with lazy Euler syncing'"
b'b"  is quaternion-based
column11: and the Euler rotation is provided only for user convenience.  However
column12: in the class
column13: we currently do this:  1. update the quaternion whenever the Euler rotation changes
column14: and 2. update the Euler rotation whenever the quaternion changes.  This PR implements the minimal change to effect the following
column15: more efficient
column16: strategy:  1. update the quaternion whenever the Euler rotation changes
column17: and 2. lazily update the Euler rotation only when it is accessed.  In addition
column18: a simple caching system is used to further prevent unnecessary computations.  This means that the class no longer needs to update anybody else.  If there is agreement that this approach works
column19: we can proceed to remove all the callbacks from the class (yay!). In addition
column20: as proposed in #11289
column21: we can eliminate some unnecessary closures. But for now
column22: I\'d like to keep this PR simple. "'

b"b' Fix sort function to be well defined (transitive) when undefined values are present.'"
b"b' Current function is broken when objects with   are present. The function is not transitive
column11: therefore presence of any such value may break the sort function
column12: leaving the render list unsorted.  This happens for a single frame any time a new object is added into the scene. The reason why it happens is field is set during the rendering (see  )
column13: but the sorting is done before the rendering (see  ).  '"

column10: b'b" Um
column11: I don\'t understand. If or are undefined
column12: uses the next criterion ( ). Why should this break the sorting?"'

column10: b"b' Let us have: = undefined  = 2 = 2  = 3 = 1  = 1  Then:  a < b (because of ) a b  It is impossible to sort such objects correctly.'"
b"b'  How does this look like after your change?'"
b'b\' Our sorting function is non-transitive
column11: and will have problems with a case such as this one:     A    B         a  2    0   b  1    2   c  undef  1  a   b   c  This is because
column12: in our sort function
column13: is treated as "equal-to-anything".  What to do about it
column14: if anything
column15: is up for debate.\''

column10: b"b' Okay
column11: I see. Because can be undefined under special circumstances
column12: the suggested approach by @OndrejSpanel seems reasonable. Otherwise it would be necessary to ensure always has a valid default value (some sort of default program).'"

column10: b'b" >Otherwise it would be necessary to ensure  always has a valid default value  It\'s better to ensure a correct value.  @OndrejSpanel Can you explain the consequence of doing nothing? In what sense is doing nothing worse than doing something arbitrary?  "'
b"b' Consequence of doing nothing is that when sorting function is ill-defined and it is impossible to sort items by the ordering defined by it
column11: sorting needs to abort and the result of the sort is undefined. The result may be partially sorted or not sorted at all.  This can happen for a single frame after adding a new object into the scene.'"

column10: b"b' >sorting needs to abort and the result of the sort is undefined  I would not phrase it that way. However
column11: I do agree with the following statement:  >[The] consequence of doing nothing is ... the result may be partially sorted or not sorted at all.  Agreed. As currently written
column12: if one object has an undefined program
column13: even the remaining objects may not be sorted correctly.  The correct solution
column14: unfortunately
column15: is to make sure is defined prior to sorting.'"

column12: rather implementation-defined.\''

column11: When would do you expect A-Frame to copy and reset the camera before rendering? It would have to happen after the [getCamera]url  call (that updates the camera with the headset pose) and before rendering. We could move the camera pose update at an earlier point out of but we want to request the pose as late as possible to get the most recent pose before render.'"

column10: b"b' Not sure if this is a bug in [gltf viewer]url  the library or the sample model
column11: but there seems to be a general issue with the rendering order if you turn on the grid in the viewer: ![renderbug]url  '"

column10: b'b\' You can hack this to look right from certain angles by fiddling with sorting and depthWrite
column11: but the robust "transparency is perfect from any angle" solution is nontrivial. Related: url \''

column10: b'b" Closing in favor of #9977.  In general
column11: you can always mitigate this issue by defining a custom render order via [Object3]url  or by setting []url  to as mentioned by @donmccurdy. However
column12: these approaches represent no holistic solution. They might fix rendering issues only in particular cases.  You can also mitigate the issue during the modeling phase by merging meshes and by avoiding the usage of multiple materials per object. The mentioned glTF asset has 60 mesh definitions which seems a bit high for such a model. A nice side effect by this optimization is a better rendering performance since you lower the amount of draw calls. You can also merge meshes in your app via [()]url  but it\'s a bit easier to do this in a DCC tool."'

column10: b"b' >Closing in favor of #9977.  What? They are separate issues. And OIT is not a panacea.  This is also not a duplicate.  You can close this if you claim it is a modeling issue
column11: and not a  issue.'"

column10: b'b" I agree with @WestLangley
column11: there\'s a couple of questions we should answer here before closing this:  1. How do other WebGL engines compare to  when it comes to transparency? From what I\'ve seen Sketchfab in particular seems to handle transparency better than .  2. What sorting algorithms do other engines use? 3. Can we document workarounds and solutions better?  4. How much will OIT improve things
column12: and at what performance cost? We can discuss this one in #9977"'

column10: b'b" Okay okay
column11: reopening^^. I\'ve seen in the past that we closed such issues and referred to OIT or modeling instead."'

column10: b"b' So

column12: or is it a modeling issue -in which case this issue can be closed again? :-)'"

column10: b"b' Refactor PointerLockControls'"
b"b' This is reasonable attempt at implementing #16160.  /ping @arodic  /ping @Mugen87 '"
b"b' There is no need to change rotation order on the camera.  Pointerlock behavior can be calculated with two quaternions then applied to camera rotation in correct order.'"
b"b' >There is no need to change rotation order on the camera.  This is exactly what the is for. If you want the Euler rotation to represent _heading_
column11: _pitch_
column12: and _roll_
column13: then you set accordingly.  In fact
column14: we should have made the default order in the first place. It would have resulted in much less user confusion. Too late now
column15: unfortunately...  >Pointerlock behavior can be calculated with two quaternions then applied to camera rotation in correct order.  Can you share your implementation of that?'"

column10: b'b"  Sure. Probably tomorrow.  Ideally
column11: users should not require knowledge of control internals to use it. If control changes camera rotation order
column12: it should be in in lock() function (not the constructor)
column13: and it should restore it to previous order in unlock(). It\'s really not that difficult to imagine how changing rotation order can mess up camera behavior. I could come up with a few examples
column14: or even create live examples but honestly it would be a waste of time. PointerLockControls is a very simple utility and it\'s trivial to implement it without mutating default camera parameters and without requiring users to reset it back to default. "'

column10: b"b' >I could come up with a few examples
column11: or even create live examples but honestly it would be a waste of time. Closing then.'"

column10: b"b' Reopened and refactored in response to feedback.'"
b'b" @arodic I\'m thinking on merging this PR and maybe you can build yours on top of this one. What do you think?"'
b'b" @mrdoob what features would make sense to merge?  I think the most crucial is the **change event**. It should be emitted on mousemove
column11: lock and unlock. This enables controls to work with applications without continuous render loop such as the editor.  Reverse vertical movement parameter is a nice to have and can be easily applied to this PR. polar angle and  angle getters
column12: I think should rely on spherical for clarity and consistency with other controls. Therefore it\'s not suitable for this implementation in my opinion "'

column10: b'b"  For better or worse
column11: that\'s the way it works in both  and Blender
column12: and I don\'t see any plausible path to changing this. The  animation system requires names to be unique _within the subtree used by an AnimationMixer_
column13: unless you bind keyframe tracks to UUIDs (which has even more serious drawbacks) or do some manual binding by reference.  I understand there are non-identity ways you might want to use
column14: but... on some level I think that\'s a request for a different feature
column15: like or  .  That said
column16: I\'d agree with doing (1) unless there\'s a reason to expect problems. If any loader was relying on that behavior
column17: it should be easy enough to change that. And if not
column18: there doesn\'t seem to be much reason to preserve an undocumented magic behavior?"'

column10: b"b' lerp and lerpVectors are not clamped (and it is great)
column11: but please fix the docs.'"

column10: b"b' Documentation of lerp and lerpVectors says: But implementation is not clamped
column11: unclamped version is more generic and useful than clamped
column12: so just please update the documentation.  url '"

column10: b'b" Would you like to do a PR with the fix? I suppose it\'s sufficient to do this: Note: It\'s necessary to change the docs of and for all vector classes (
b"b'  >>alpha interpolation factor.  Thing is
column11: the accepted PR did not do that. '"

column10: b'b\' >But implementation is not clamped  _Nowhere_ in the documentation does it say the input is clamped -nor does it say the output is clamped.  >alpha interpolation factor in the closed interval [0
column11: 1]  performs linear interpolation _between_ two values. If a value less than zero is passed in
column12: the result is not linear interpolation
column13: it is linear _extrapolation_.  Personally
column14: I would leave the documentation as-is because that is the conventional intent of the method.  If you insist on a change
column15: you can do this:  >alpha interpolation factor
column16: typically in the closed interval [0
column17: 1]  But doing so violates the meaning of "lerp"
column18: so I would prefer the existing documentation.\''

column10: b"b'   does not validate inputs
column11: so a user is free to pass in values outside the nominal range.  This may or may not produce reasonable results. In this case it does produce a reasonable result
column12: but it is not a lerp.  I think the docs should document the method for nominal inputs only.  I would like to reopen this issue so we can further discuss...'"

column10: b'b\' One more thing... the docs say  >Linearly interpolates between this vector and [page:Vector2 v]
column11: where alpha is the distance along the line  is not a "distance". If it were
column12: it would be sized in world units (for example
column13: meters).  is unitless; it is a percentage. So the docs should say
column14: >where alpha is the percent distance along the line  I do not think should be documented to accept a negative percentage.  If users want to pass in a negative percentage
column15: that is their business. \''

column10: b"b' Hi @WestLangley
column11: The idea was just to document what the current implementation actually does: If alpha is in [0
column12: 1] the result is the interpolation
column13: but if alpha is outside of [0
column14: 1] the result is extrapolation.  Other implementations (i.e. Unity) have both versions: lerp and lerpUnclamped
column15: so another solution is to add new methods but the current implementation covers both cases
column16: so I think it is just needed to clarify that in the docs. The idea is to avoid the need of  read the actual source code to decide if we can use the method with alpha outside [0
column17: 1] and what is the expected result in that case.'"

column10: b"b' @mnesarco Thanks for your reply. It was not intended that a user would pass in a value outside the interval [ 0
column11: 1 ].  Out of curiosity
column12: what was your use case for passing in a negative value for alpha?'"

column10: b"b' Hi @WestLangley
column11: I use lerpVectors(v1
column12: v2) method to calculate extrapolated points in the same line represented by v1->v2. I can write a method for it in my code
column13: but I prefer to not reinvent the wheel if the method is already available and does exactly what I need.  I have a segment from A to B
column14: and I need to calculate a point
column15: in the same line but before A
column16: in that case I use lerpVectors(A
column17: B
column18: alpha) with alpha  1 if I need a point after B but in the same line.'"

column10: b"b'  That sounds like a good solution and makes the implementation more clear.'"
b"b' @Mugen87 if you want
column11: I can submit another PR with the new methods and doc updates'"

column10: b"b' I think I would keep just one method and make this change to the docs:  >alpha interpolation factor
column11: typically in the closed interval [0
column12: 1]  and then
column13: >where alpha is the percent distance along the line '"

column10: b'b" The primary reason is that  does not validate inputs.  I hope keeping one method and updating the docs as suggested satisfies @mnesarco \'s concerns."'
